124463007.review:
Can you recall the scariest media experience of your life? I'll take a guess and say that it probably wasn't something that was meant to be scary, e.g. horror. Rather, it's probably either something that was unintentionally scary or kids' entertainment; something that, at its core, is not horror whatsoever. That's where the purest, most potent fears are created.

In other words, the best way to create horror is to not create horror. And that's exactly that Omocat did when she made OMORI. A huge, childish, innocent game which [b]seems[/b] to only exist to deliver its true emotional payload with maximum force. 

Mind, the game doesn't hide the fact that at its very core it is in fact horror. Both the trailer and the screenshots show you glimpses of the darkness that awaits you at the bottom of the staircase. But that's the thing: it [i]awaits[/i]. You know its there, all the while you play a "normal" game about a kid hanging out with his friends in a childhood fantasy land for just about long enough to [i]forget[/i]. And then it reminds you of its existence, looks you straight in the eye, and... leaves you alone again. Until you forget again. But your subconsciousness won't forget: it will constantly whisper this dissonant song of quiet anxiety which becomes the background radiation of OMORI's universe.

So, for the most part you play a kiddy JRPG. But uh-oh, that's also not quite true. To avoid spoilers, let's just say it's not a kid's dream land as much as it's a kid's dream land that's significantly distorted by nostalgia, fading memories and trauma. Remember when I said that this part of the main game [b]seems[/b] only to exist to strengthen the horror? Yes, seems. In the grand scheme of things, it also establishes the world, the characters, the events of the past, and - perhaps most importantly - serves as a snapshot of sorts, snapshot of what the world seemed like back then. You know how that big plushie from your childhood seemed like this lumbering giant, but when you look at the photographs you can see that it was in fact quite small? This is what I'm talking about here.

This is important because the general theme of the game is "dealing with your past" - in more ways than one. But that's all I'm going to say on that topic.

Oh, and if you've been playing indie games long enough to believe that games designed by visual artists tend to be pretty but boring, shallow and generally not very thought through, don't you worry. This is a rare exception. The game design is not only fun, it's also quite fresh - for example, instead of elements, the battle system revolves around a mood system. Anger, sadness, happiness. Happiness is strong against anger, anger is strong against sadness, sadness is strong against happiness; many mid-and-late game fights revolve around cleverly managing and exploiting the moods of not only your party, but also the opponents. I've never seen anything like that, and I've seen quite a bit.

If there's one thing that bothers me about the game, it's the portrayal of some elements of depression. Omori (the character) clearly suffers from some kind of emotional deficiency; not only his face barely changes expressions, he's also drained of colour, unlike literally everything else. So far so good, this is a pretty good representation. But the problem is that in spite of this, he's loved and surrounded by friends. Like, how does that work? Anyone who's suffered from even a minor depressive episode knows that when the 𝙱𝙻𝙰𝙲𝙺 𝙵𝙾𝙶 takes over, people tend to see you as a drag, a bore, uninteresting, and often unattractive due to your lowered ability to care for your looks. Mentally ill people usually end up alone, and not by choice - they're abandoned by their "friends" and family. Maybe my experience has something to do with the different way society reacts to depression in men and women; or maybe this is in fact intentional, and this inconsistency is meant to be a clue that something is very wrong here.

There are other things about this game that I could write about, such as the fact that the soundtrack contains 170+ tracks, 4 hours in total. Or the sheer volume of hand-drawn art this game has. But in such an emotionally potent game as OMORI, these things pretty much don't matter. They're the background, only helping to bring the game's emotionality front and center. If you've decided to descend the staircase of this game, as I believe you should, a small reminder, just in case:

At the bottom, that darkness is still there.

[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/42922988/]Curator Page[/url]

139344886.review:
Before I actually played OMORI myself, I heard positive words about it, but at the time, I didn't really want to try it out, due to my laziness, until recently. To be honest, when I was buying this game, I thought I'd just try it out for an hour or two and then not proceed further. How foolish I was back then... on my very first game session, I was stuck in the game for 4 hours straight and liked it, totally not expecting that. The point of no return for me, though, had become the Junkyard area with the track playing in this location, and that's when I literally fell in love with the game.

I managed to finish OMORI within 40+ hours for the first time, while most people finish it within around 20 hours, but it was all about taking my time and sticking nose in every corner I notice, interact with everything that's interactable, and immerse into the story. Actually, everything about this piece of art is brilliant, making it hard for me to talk about anything specific, because all of the aspects of OMORI are intertwined and each of them plays a significant role: gameplay, characters, story, visuals, and, of course, MUSIC (with caps, yes). All combined, I somehow felt nostalgic for something I never really had. I felt familiar with locations as if I was actually there, spending my summer vacations. And characters felt like they're my friends or siblings. This is pure magic.

This game is one of the prime examples of why story-based games are valuable for players and for the game industry overall. They are unlike online session or grinding kind of games, in which you can spend hundreds or thousands of hours. It's not necessarily a bad thing, to spend that much time for a game, but something story-based, which might not even take 50 hours to finish, can end up being much more memorable and make you feel alive, refreshing from routine, carry you through a roller coaster of emotions, ending with a thought "What a blast it has been". In case of OMORI, you'll additionally have so much to think about afterwards, look up at discussion forums, come up with certain ideas. And most likely, tear up or cry. Fun fact: no piece of media has ever drained so many tears from me, even though I wasn't ugly crying, haha.

A couple of important parts about the game: it DOES contain psyschological horror elements, it covers quite sensitive topics and it demonstrates some things which might be hard to take for certain players, be advised about it. And, if you decided to play this game or started playing it and you're determined to finish it, try to avoid spoilers. It is important.

This is the first time I'm writing an actual review for a game, I really don't have expreience in writing those :p But I got this inspiration to deliver my feelings and some points about OMORI, as it felt important to me. Maybe I really needed to get through such expreience for a long time, and I hadn't even known about it, until recently.

For anyone who reads this, thank you for your time!

145024047.review:
This is the story I am not going to tell anyone, but a few anonymous people on the Steam webpage. The writing I did has only one goal: to make a conclusion of my own thoughts and emotions that came up in my mind throughout playing this game.

I came to Omori as a normal, mentally stable fellow, without that many sad and depressing thoughts before playing. I consider myself a person who will never complain to somebody about my emotions and thoughts. I'll never cry to anyone and will never say how bad I'm feeling; that's okay for me. I never had depression and expected nothing from this game. A month ago, I decided to finally quit video games because of the intensive studies that are going to begin this September. I'll have to move to a completely new country for me, alone. I will work hard, and there is no way I could spend my free time in front of a computer. I considered Omori as my last single-player video game of my teenage years and for the foreseeable future.

My first play was at night. Being completely alone helped me understand this game correctly. My first session lasted for six non-stop hours, and I've never felt what I felt during this play. There is no other video game that is able to make you feel that blank post-gaming syndrome constantly, like Omori did. I felt it from the beginning until the end, whether I was in front of a computer or not. I'm still wondering if this "hollow" feeling will ever fully leave me. When I decided that this is enough for today, I went to the bathroom and spent almost an hour there, thinking. The main subject was my childhood.

The thoughts of my childhood became a sad ghost that follows me every night and day. I think about it every time I have to solve some task about my university admission or studies, every time I walk through a place that was special only for you and a few people you knew back then. Do they still remember it as I do? Do they still cherish it as I do? Will they ever come back here with a desperate hope of seeing some of us or just to see it again?

That night, I felt completely miserable. There is no way to get back there. There is no way I could ever talk to all my good old friends again, no way we could gather again and do the things that kids like us usually did. Some part of them is lost in a big city with their own troubles. I'm sure that they have forgotten how great it was together. Some have left the country forever, and some are even dead. Money wasn't a concern in my childhood. There was no war, and I wasn't afraid that I'd never see my parents again due to a Russian rocket attack. When I was 12, my only worry was spending another summer with my friends, with a stash of snacks prohibited by my mother, and that limited version of Coca-Cola that is no longer produced. I never thought about all of this before playing OMORI. I never missed my childhood times and never dreamed about those times. Omori's headspace is a mirror of our infantile times we all had and miss.

This masterpiece is not about gameplay, graphics, or storyline. There is no way you can rate it separately from your own mind and the changes that occur in it during the play. This game is about nostalgic, infantile, pure emotions that emerge from the hidden part of your soul and will never leave you until your death.

There is a theory of the "last dream," which means that when you die, your brain will produce a last, long dream—some even call it heaven. I am sure that this "heaven" will be some kind of headspace, but with your own friends, games, and troubles. I hope that I'll be able to feel these emotions of a little kid who just minds his own business, playing games with friends and dreaming again. Wait for me, my friends. I'll play with you once again, someday. Even if I have to die for this, it'll be a worthy reward. 10/10, the best game I've ever played.

142628811.review:
I have not had a game sink its claws as deep as Omori has done to me in a long time. From the beginning sections of the game, I found myself emotionally invested in the characters and story to a degree that I have never experienced before. From my initial impressions, Omori managed to retain this level of investment throughout my 32-hour playthrough. 

Unfortunately, I cannot provide insight into the story for fear of spoiling you of the experience. I went in completely blind without reading any online reviews (some of which mention key story beats), so I suggest you do the same. What I can reveal, is the game features prominent themes of depression, suicide, and guilt, and these themes are core to the story Omori is telling. 

Omori’s main gameplay loop centres around a top-down perspective when exploring the overworld, and a JRPG turn-based battle system that focuses on controlling four party members, each with their own stats and abilities. Unlike other JRPG’s however, Omori chooses to ditch elemental status effects (e.g Stun, Sleep, Frozen) and implements a system centred around emotion. Each character is able to be happy, sad, or angry, and each emotion comes with their stat changes, along with their own strengths and weaknesses. 

Outside of encounters, players explore a beautiful pixel-art world full of colour, mystery and intrigue. Each location in the game is unique, and no two areas feel repetitive or instil a feeling of déjà vu. The world is littered with a good variety of side quests, which I recommend you do – not only to receive the items/gear as rewards for completion, but also to experience the heart-warming stories the side quests are able to convey. Few games can make side content worth doing, more often than not these missions feel as though they are only present to pad out the games’ run time, however Omori manages to make these missions a meaningful addition that can be a nice change of pace from the game’s dark narrative. 

Omori’s soundtrack perfectly complements the game’s central themes. Some tracks are whimsical and upbeat, while others incite a feeling of hopelessness and dread within the player, and each track is masterfully utilized to enhance the emotions the game is trying to convey within its story beats and exploration. Each track has a purpose and emotion tied to it, and multiple genres of music are featured, ranging from retro to orchestral. 

In conclusion, Omori is a meticulously crafted experience that tells an engaging story and leaves a major impact upon the player. All of the aspects of the game are so important to the story telling and emotional palpability of the world, and they meld together seamlessly. This game was an emotional rollercoaster, with many ups and downs which left me in equal parts smiling through the lighter tones of the story, and dejected at the more depressing content. I loved this game, and I hope you enjoy this experience as much as I did.

144588875.review:
Omori is a two-dimensional RPG with psychological horror elements. The game portrays concepts such as anxiety, depression, trauma and suicide. If you’re looking for an adventure game to pass the time and you’re not easily triggered I highly recommend this game.

The player assumes the role of a teenage boy whose alter-ego is called ‘Omori’. The game is more or less split into halves, in two different settings, Headspace and Faraway Town. In simple terms, Headspace is essentially Omori’s escape from reality. The two polarizing visual settings are improved upon, by the soundscape being that of juxtaposition as well, reinforcing the mood!

The plot of this game is elaborate and is expanded upon throughout the lengthy gameplay. Despite its length the game never feels boring due to the elaborate, colorful, expansive and polarizing score. The music has great success in making the player feel immersed in the dream world, Headspace, at all times; it is able to relay darker and more sinister tones when necessary. 

The first sound cue ‘Titel’ is played whenever we load the game. The music sounds empty, there is a continual, soft white noise under a solitary piano making it sound sparse. This white noise is not in the same key as the piano making it dissonant, adding to the feeling that something is wrong.   

The Piano sounds cold in this particular setting as the instrument has no vibrato, the melody is discordant and we are in a minor key. There is a lack of any richness, denying the listener, all hope from this passage of music. The notes are also disjunct, making them unpredictable and unsettling. To further this atmosphere, the cue contains no perfect cadences, the music cannot resolve, perhaps relating to how the characters in the game cannot resolve their emotions and/or traumatic experiences they've endured.

The game talks about the importance of friends and family, being there for one another. The tune is played on the left hand and the lower chords, that reinforce that melody, are in the right hand. The right hand could represent Mari, Omori’s older sister, while the lost-sounding melody represents Omori.

The next cue we will be looking at is called ‘White Space’. This cue plays when we are present in White Space, which occurs often. White space appears in contrast to the rest of the game as it is an abstract plain, devoid of all colour and life. We travel to white space usually after a traumatic event in the game. The cue is simple and effective, as the short repetitive musical patterns work in tandem with the stark atmosphere of the white setting. The use of an electronic synth works well with the striking white visuals and the computer found in white space. The melody’s pattern is descending but ends on a note that is higher than the first, making for an ambiguous melody line. This pattern plays twice in a major key and twice in the minor key. This gives the player a sense of unease knowing that despite our isolation, we are not safe. The descending patterns and minor key sound alarming. In contrast, the high note at the end of phrases and major sections sounds positive. Overall, this bit of music leaves us in suspense.

The last cue we will be looking at plays in the dreamland, Headspace, and is titled ‘Three Bar Logos’. It is a memorable, light-hearted, heroic piece of music. This music plays as you fight off ‘baddies’ in Headspace. The heroic melody is created by the intervals that sound reassured and are whole-tonal. The cue is polyrhythmic and frantic, making it sound like a fight. The main tune is then punctuated by a rhythmically augmented syncopation, they are short punch-like sounds, ideal for the fight element of this game.

Overall, the music enriches the player's understanding of this already plot-rich game. It also helps enhance all elements of the game, whether it’s setting pace, combat segments, and emotional or pinnacle hit points in the game. It’s a musical rhapsody full of colour and excitement as well as masterful horror elements and suspense.

128332132.review: A powerful story-rich game that almost made me cry. The horror element is more passive than active, similar to jumpscares in horror games. The game's uneasy and anxious atmosphere in one section and the cute and lighthearted segments contrast nicely with how the story is presented in the other. The little secrets and hidden easter eggs make the world feel more natural and ready to pique our interest in the world we are presented with. Omori is like climbing a mountain, reaching the peak, and then immediately climbing a bigger mountain. Sure, climbing the mountain is a big part of the fun, but sometimes you just want to sit back and take in the scenery. To see this masterpiece, you'll have to play it yourself. I went in blind, and it was the best experience of my life, aside from the severe depression I suffered. Overall, Omori is a fantastic and impactful game that I believe everyone should play, but be prepared for its excruciating pacing. I rate it 10/10. I highly recommend this game.

138610556.review:
If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

6 tablespoons unsalted butter

1/2 cup white sugar

1/2 cup brown sugar

1/4 cup water

1/4 teaspoon cinnamon

1 pinch salt

5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced

1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).

Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.

Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.

Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.

Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.

Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Where do I even begin?
This game has such lovely aesthetics, a haunting and catchy OST with amazing bosses and relatable characters! It's both a cute and comedy-rich RPG that warms your heart, and a soul-crushing but very realistic take on depression, anxiety & trauma; as well as how these struggles can cause tension amongst those you're closest to. I would recommend this game to everyone I know, 100% - though I will say, I don't recommend this if you're in a poor mental state. I relate to the story this game tells extremely hard and I believe it depicts these feelings of trauma and moving on beautifully! It makes you laugh, cry and honestly just jam out to the spectacular beats!

128625602.review:
This game surprised me. I didn’t know what to expect going into this except a wacky and wild adventure with some spooks, and while all that was present, there was so much more. The amount of hidden details, hints towards the truth in the story, and things you can simply do in this game is nuts!

I loved the contrast between the imaginary world and reality, and the fact that there’s different routes to take on really adds to the replay value. The side quests are cool and add life to both worlds, but there are times where I wish there were easier ways to keep track of quests and know where to go for them.

The music is fantastic, the psychological horror is done in a great way that isn’t too much or too little, and the characters are hard not to like. I can’t help but recommend this, and I’ll definitely replay it in the future to do all the things I missed during my blind, initial playthrough towards the good ending. And if any of you go for that good ending, be sure to water Basil’s plants. He’d appreciate it :)

125144958.review:
When this game first came out i would have wholeheartedly recommended it, it's one of the best RPGs out there, even if it does a lot wrong it stands out as a unique and enjoyable experience in a sea of mediocre and "samey" games. That is until the console exclusive content came out, honestly i have no idea why there isn't MORE negative reviews after it came out.
From what i've heard, the content is in the game files (i've heard some conflicting reports so not 100%, even if it wasn't though it'd be very easy to add) but just... Wasn't added??? The developer (Omocat) has had no comment on this fact in the around half a year this content has been out and chooses to instead drop merch and ignore peoples questions. I avoided the content and tried not to say anything as you never know whats going on behind the scenes, but at this point it's fair to say that it's likely never coming and Omocat cucked those who supported her and her game.
If you want to play this game, either play it on a console or get it on Xbox gamepass. You dont just miss out on a little content playing on steam, you miss out on a lot, specifically in one of the games main alternate routes. If steam is your only option i would still recommend just biting the bullet and playing it on steam as the game is amazing with or without the new content and worth experiencing, but if you have the other options take them 100%. The fact that this game hasn't had a price gouge on steam since this whole new content controversy happened is also disgusting.
I could go on a whole rant about how Omocat doesn't give a fuck about those who originally supported her and just wants to milk those who enjoy the game for every penny but i wont, if you're curious i recommend looking into her long list of controversies yourself (basically everything with the original kickstarter for the game), others have explained it far better than i can. I love this game and it truly pisses me off how horribly it has been handled for all these years by Omocat.
If by some miracle the new content does come out i'll change my review, by as of now naw.

When I first played the game, I got to the [spoiler]Pluto (Expanded)[/spoiler] and the my laptop blue screened so I lost all progress... Second time I played, I got to the [spoiler]Barn[/spoiler] scene, then blue screened again... Two times I lost progress because im dumb, and I had to restart... Third time is the charm, am I right?

Playing it again, all those moments I experienced before, it felt new... Because Omori feels easy to emotionally invest in. Fights I already did were easier, but still fun. The writing of course is horrifying, but it's so damn good. All the stuff I experienced again, and experienced for the first time, it was all... Worth while. Seeing this story through... I cried so damn much. It was very mentally taxing, but it was so, so worth it. The music, graphics, story, atmosphere, all of the game is just... feels perfect. 

I cannot make a review that does the game justice. Thank you Omocat and everyone else involved for such a wonderful experience. Merry Christmas and happy anniversary <3

135825915.review:
I already suspected it would be something to remember when I decided to start playing this game on New Year's Eve 2022. But even though I was immediately hooked, even though the unique style drew me in, the characters were both adorable and genuine, even though I was amazed the game had three whole albums worth of soundtrack, even though there was the grip of a deep and unsettling mystery around my heart, despite it all, I still wasn't prepared to be unknowingly playing what turned out to be the most emotionally intense horror game of my life.

While there are few games I'd recommend more than OMORI, this one goes all the way round to make me careful again with who I'd recommend it to. Overall one of the best experiences I ever had.

135332153.review: I am not the kind of person who tends to write reviews about the games I play. However, in this case, I felt like writing something decent for this masterpiece because this game hit me harshly with its fun yet disturbing atmosphere.[h1] The game's interesting dialogue and storyline [/h1]The dialogue is written amazingly and full of emotions in a way that makes you feel connected to the charismatic characters as you met them for years, with each character having a unique personality. The game's ambiance can also bring you a perfect kind of suspense and psychological horror that makes you feel pretty much curious to discover what's going on in the protagonist's mind and the entire game's well-written story. Trust me, try to play the game as blind as possible and see for yourself how interesting this experience can be.[h1] The gameplay and its weird world [/h1]Although inspired by the Mother series, its turn-based combat is extremely unique in lots of ways and pretty fun once you get fully used to it, with lots of different skills to equip and experiment with its odd yet exciting combat. The world is full of interesting NPCs and stuff to do as well as side quests with rewards that can help you engage against more powerful foes, making the exploration very satisfactory, fulfilling you with funny and weird dialogues from certain NPCs that come across your way.[h1] The amazing official soundtrack [/h1]The soundtrack is extremely well-made and astonishing to listen to, with each area having a unique battle theme and making you feel excited to fight your enemies. Each time I heard one new interesting song I instantly went to look for it on the internet and I even plan on buying this game's amazing soundtrack to both listen to it and support its developers.[h1] Ending [/h1]Honestly, this is now considered one of my top 10 favorite games of all time and it has a special place in the bottom of my heart, I loved every second of it![b] 10/10 I got depression after finishing Omori. [/b]

144718332.review:
OMORI - The Joys and Pains of Life

Disclaimer, I was gifted this game and while i will talk about the story, i only will cover its themes and will not name any characters simply to not spoil the game for people but will place a spoiler warning and cover it tho if the tags don't work then just don't read the story section. 

OMORI is a game i first heard about by some Youtubers a few years back and then again last year by my partner. I heard its praise but oddly none of its negatives which tells me something isn't being told. 

OMORI is a story where u are a young man who appears in a colorful world but lacks color himself for some reason. Over the course of the game you will learn that not everything is what it seems and the truth can be something hard to accept. So with that lets get on with the review.

WARNING - LIGHT SPOILERS AHEAD I WILL SAY WHEN THE SPOILERS ARE OVER IF U WISHED TO AVOID THEM.

The story:
[spoiler]OMORI story tackles a number of themes a lot of games avoid. Personally depression in young people, self harm and the thoughts of ending one's life. The game cleverly hides this from the player at the start by dropping us in a colorful world which everything seems happy, tho even then we get hints something isn't right. The choice of using a young teen as our protag is great as it allows many people both teens themselves or adults to understand the feelings our protag is going though. The use of making our in game colors black and white compare to everything else is also meant to give u a feel something off. Another thing of praise is how it handles each theme without feeling like it not been given careful thought on how to portray it. However the game does a number of endings which while nice, playing the game though a number of times  to get these endings, you never get the same feeling the first run gives as it does a good job at keeping the player in the dark until the right time to reveal important plot/story. This however is why i bring up the number of endings, see once you know the mystery the game kind of loses a lot in the terms of storytelling as the game rely on the player not knowing to always keeping the player on their toes. Lastly is some of the endings are hard to figure out as the game sometimes flat out fails to give the info to point the in the right place to get those endings, however the game does give a hint early on on how to get the true ending tho it doesn't make it too easy to notice.[/spoiler] 

THE SPOILERS ARE OVER

Gameplay:
OMORI plays a old school RPG or if people played the mother games (Earthbound in the west) then you feel right at home. Combat works on a turn based system where u do all our characters moves which then play out which allows you to set up a number of combats and strats. Grinding is kind as the game doesn't need much to beat it and each boss fight feels different and enjoyable. There is a fast travel system which only at select times which can't be used to get around the world. Lastly each party member covers a job which u normally find in RPGs. You have a Damage dealer, your tank, your healer and your support/debuffer. I would talk more about Game play but the game does a good job explaining these to you which i feel i would just be rehashing as most of it is explained to you in the first hour of the game. 

Art/sound:
OMORI boasts a lovely art style which feels like you looking at a young person's drawings and each character and foe looks great. While the game has no voice acting, the game covers that by the wide array of sound effects and music. Speaking of the Music the OST is honest one of the best i heard in a while where each area and main bosses have their own song which are all great to listen to as they go from the calm and peaceful to the dark while bosses ost's feel like a epic fight or fitting for the boss in question. Last detail is focus on our main cast as each of them have a number of expressions which are well illustrated and really brings each one to life. Even a number of NPCs even have a wide number of expressions each look great. 

Conclusion:
OMORI is a game where i personally feel a lot of people can relate and connect with. While some of its themes can be unsettling to some, the devs have done a wonderful job at making sure they give each one the careful thought which is needed to use them. If you not a fan of turn based game play i would avoid the game because a good part of the game is combat and some areas can last awhile. With all that i would recommend OMORI as for the price of £16 at the time of review you will get value for your money and experience a story which feels well written and even can put a number of AAA games to shame.

However, even with such a beautifully and strikingly written script, there were many illogical and difficult things to ignore in my mind. I'm not going to spoil the surprise by talking about these, I want you to experience it for yourself. I also think that this game is not for everyone and will not appeal to everyone.

124718776.review:
I've never felt more emotionally invested in a game's story and characters, and it's made me cry both out of sadness and happiness.
It's also made me more appreciative of a lot in my personal life.
And some of the game's music, and the events and atmosphere they relate to, will be stuck in my head for the forseeable future.

note: this game is spoiler heavy throughout, and you should avoid any kind of discussion or content related to the game until you complete a playthrough. Also, OMORI is a long and slow-paced game, and is best experienced with you in control. Despite the game's storytelling focus, immersion is an important aspect of OMORI, and it doesn't work as well watching someone else play.

136988393.review:
Omori is a game that takes you on a journey. It explores the safe haven you created for yourself. You constantly think back to your childhood, to the simpler times where things didn't matter, nothing weighed on you heavily, and time with your friends felt like it would never end. And yet... the play ends, the curtains fall, and you wake up isolated from everything you've ever come to know and love. You have choices to make. Will you be able to make the choices to discover your true reality?

Omori's story shows how the main character deals with the stress of all his fears. Visiting this safe haven, headspace, shows what the main character holds onto dearly. And yet, the cheerful and colorful backdrops of the world are all a facade to fuel your extreme escapism. The deeper you go into the story, the more you'll realize that life is unfair. That losing something important to you is just the first domino to fall, which cascades into everything around you changing, whether you like it or not. See how the character interacts with these fallen dominoes through the choices you make in the game. 

Depending on how you view depression, anxiety, and suicide, you will either resonate with the story and deeply enjoy it, or you will stay for the silly banter between the characters and the wacky dialogue. Enjoy the humor, stay for the story, and beware the truth. It will break your heart. It broke mine. 

10/10.

137821608.review:
Overall, OMORI is a gem, or in other words, a ride that deserves it's spot of "Top 3 of Psychological Horror", despite the horror factor not being constant. It's a rough diamond, but easily a must-play if you haven't seen *any* spoilers before stumbling here. It's perfect if you waltz in blind.

No, it's not Undertale.

It's a generally well-written game with a quite likeable cast, making you feel bad for said cast (which it does pretty well at a few points), room for interpretation and discussion, nice art, good music, interesting-ish plot, pretty high attention to detail, leitmotifs that count as detail, foreshadowing, and memorable-to-excellent events of a variety.
You could wish that you could wipe your memory and play it again, and... well, at-least i did.

The large amounts of good is dulled and dented by mistakes, missed opportunities, and things that could have been improved on from the devs side, one of the more apparent issues being the *slow* beginning the game has, along with non-excellent pacing on some parts, which causes people to say that the entire game feels like a slog (which varies from person to person). I didn't really notice that too well, aside from minor annoyance in some parts.

Shouldn't forget about the issues that rise if you aren't bent towards what the game wants you to feel.
Though, as you somehow will not notice any issues at first, you'll be fine as long as you don't think about them, because there is stuff to awe over. As i said, the game's a ride, at-least on a first run.

Ignoring the last (negative) part, it's certainly one of the better games that i have played recently, maybe ever. The positive traits make up a great game, which... well, obviously has something to do with the Overwhelmingly Positive ratings and some people describing it to be life-changing. I don't know if the game is "lighting caught in a bottle", but some feel like it is. The negative traits or issues don't ruin it, but you can easily have an issue with them. 

There's a reason that i kind of had an obsession with the game (Or "brainrot"), as have other people, despite the list of things that i disliked. Still, some of those things will only become problematic once you have finished the game once, and i won't actually mention them, because, in-case somebody actually reads this, their experience could be tainted.



And... that's it. Feel free to ask questions, as the comments are not locked.
Maybe look at the other positive reviews of the game if you want to, though, they are *far* more positive. Negative ones also tend to lead to heavily into negativity, so it would be hard to find a balanced take.

Alright, have a good day.

Omori is a wonderful RPG that's reminiscent of Earthbound. 143298766.review:
(This review is extremely negative! OMORI is still my 2nd favorite game of all time. This is some very tough love!) To start, I still recommend this game, but it is not for everyone.

To put it bluntly, this game is long. Super long. The average playtime to finish this game is 20 hours, and most of that time is not spent progressing the plot. It’s spent doing endless fetch quests, roaming around, fighting hordes of enemies, and reading so much dialogue that it can put some people to sleep.	 

HEAD SPACE: While I could write about every single part of the game, and critique how it could’ve been better, the entire rest of head space is essentially the same thing and so boring it can be summarized in a few paragraphs. Basically, you spend about 90% of your playtime in head space where the plot does not move forward. You just do a bunch of boring, pointless side quests that take forever. 
You do puzzles that are painfully easy. You fight billions of the same enemy, and most of the time turn your brain off and just spam the attack button, and this isn’t even scratching the surface on how boring head space is. It got to the point that it took me a month and 13 days to finish this game because I kept taking breaks after enduring this slog fest. 
This whole thing combined leads to a repetitive cycle where you trudge through headspace hoping to reach the point where the plot progresses and you enter the real world, which usually only occurs at the end of each segment of head space. So you get a quick spooky event about the “truth,” then get sent to the real world.

THE REAL WORLD: The real world consists of a few fetch quests and missions, and has some of the main problems from before. The best thing though is that it actually moves the central plot forward, and isn’t entirely pointless in the grand scheme of things. However the main problem with the real world is that there are so many moments of character development that should be mandatory, such as the description KEL gives about HERO’s depression when you interact with the Gravestone. I didn’t even know about this in my playthrough, and it's a pretty big plot point that should be expressed.

I’d also like to elaborate on the combat for a moment. The combat system with emotions is unique, but rarely utilized. Even if you wanted to use it for yourself you have 4 party members whose emotions need to be turned. That means 4 turns of using “Cheer,” or “Sad Poem,” or “Annoy,” (Plus an extra turn if the enemy’s emotion needs to be changed) In these 4 turns, you could deal so much damage, or be dealt so much damage that it becomes entirely pointless. (And yes, I am aware of the items that make your entire party or foes a specific emotion, but those are later in the game and are classified as items, so they are meant to be single use and “powerful.”)

Finally, the main part of the game that even kept me playing: The story and writing. To start, the game is very cheesy when it comes to its characters. I thought that this would be isolated to head space alone, but no, it carries over to the real world. Since the writing style stays the same, and none of the teenagers speak like teenagers (They rarely curse at all. This game talks about suicide, so the game can handle curse words. Curse words are usually the best way to separate fantasy from reality because yes, people do curse in stressful situations and it helps emphasize the importance of the situation), the game ends up being pretty unrealistic and feels like you're reading a manga, not seeing an actual friend group going through a hard time.
A good example of this is AUBREY. In about 3 days, after seeing SUNNY fully basically for the first time since MARI’s death, and going through various mental breakdowns, AUBREY goes through the classic Family Guy “Aw geez, I’ve been a real jerk,” then makes up with the entire party of friends. So you're telling me a person who held a grudge against their prior beloved friend group for years, to the point of which doing physical harm to them would just lose that grudge in days? Yeah, okay.

This game also terribly conveys depression. Suicide is a game mechanic, for some fucking reason, which is so insensitive and strange. The bad ending of the game also is just SUNNY killing himself with a (banger) song playing, which is just edgy and unnecessary. These moments seem to be just there for shock value, nothing more.
The game wants to convey that SUNNY has depression, but instead shows that SUNNY is scared of spiders, heights, and swimming, and does not want to go outside. So basically SUNNY just has a bunch of phobias, and is extremely fucking guilty because of the twist (more on that in a moment). 
SUNNY is also never smiling, ever. Which is strange, because most stories about suicide (with personal experience here, too) are shocking to surrounding friends and family because the person who committed suicide never seemed to express being depressed, or them in a state where they’d want to commit suicide
But OMOCAT has a very 1 dimensional view of depression. The game portrays people who are depressed as “Depressed people are sad. They never smile. They commit suicide,” when it is far more complex than that.

Now, coming to possibly the worst part of this game, the twist ending. We learn that SUNNY and BASIL killed MARI by pushing her down the stairs, then framing it as a suicide. So everything prior, SUNNY and BASIL’s “depression,” it's not depression. It's guilt. MARI was never suicidal, she was killed. Which essentially means that what could’ve been an interesting take on depression (as MARI was always so happy and vibrant) is destroyed by the fact that she never committed suicide and that it was framed. So all portrayals of depression in this game are fucking stupid and do not compare at all to the real world.

Also, the twist makes no fucking sense. So MARI gets pushed by SUNNY down the stairs. Then she falls on a fragmented violin. If she wasn’t bleeding before, she is now. Then, SUNNY drags her bloodied corpse back up the stairs, and lays her in her bed. So now there is blood everywhere across the house. Then, SUNNY and BASIL take her body (which is still dripping blood everywhere) to a tree, hoist up her 15 year old body with 12 year old noodle limbs, and then proceed to tie a noose around her head (which is harder than it looks.) 

Then the police had to either:
A: Be extremely stupid and not notice the violin shards in the body.
B: Not to be called, and the murder scene covered up by the parents. Also, we have to assume that SUNNY’s mother did this on her own, because the father presumably left SUNNY because of this incident. Leaving your entire family is a big thing, and it would make no sense for the father to cover up the murder and then leave. He would most likely keep the murder to himself, but leave in disgust.

Then the game portrays SUNNY and BASIL as sympathetic and innocent. Are you fucking kidding me? The plan to cover it up as a suicide is ridiculous enough for 12 year old “innocent boys,” but even if they did come up with this plan, the adrenaline rush to cover it up would’ve been long gone after SUNNY put MARI back in her bed.
This would be actually very interesting if the story was more of a “who-dun-it,” and we were watching psychopaths coming up with their plan, but instead we’re supposed to be watching innocent boys who made a mistake and are supposed to be forgiven and tell the truth. Yeah right.

The thing is, there was even no need for this twist ending. I understand how subjective it may be, and you can fight tooth and nail claiming that “The ending is believable, it's about being honest with yourself, etc.” But if the game really wanted to dive into depression, it could’ve instead explored the very real situation of a person who appears to be happy and vibrant committing suicide. Instead we have a twist ending more because of “shock” than because of telling a good emotional story.

141829691.review:
+very good characters, I pretty much liked the entire main cast + some side characters.
+fun battle system with it's emotion system. The combat is further enhanced by "energy" which you can accumulate for a variety of follow up attacks depending on character and your choice or unleash a powerful all-out attack.
+this game really gave me this feeling that the devs enjoyed making it - these kind of games make me smile or outright laugh the easiest.
+the theme is dark, however this is not constant, but rather makes itself rarely noticeable. I really liked this balance, making the game overall seemingly lightweight, but of course still having a very serious narrative.
+I really like the drawing style this game tries to pull off. It took a bit of getting used to, but now I like it, because it conveys the characters emotions really well

-battle system is at first quite confusing, because of the lack of in depth tutorials
-sometimes the puzzles felt more like a chore rather than a fun thing to solve
-side quests are very hard to keep up with. Often times you'd check how far you are in a specific quest route, only to receive a very vague description. Other times you are supposed to meet the quest giver x. However, if you don't remember who x is, then good luck finding them. If this wasn't a problem, I'd have for sure done all quests, since this game doesn't seem to be swamped with them.


Overall an excellent game that is held back by basically nothing. If you like RPGs with a good narrative/characters, or are looking for a more serious story, then this game is for you.

It has one of the best OST's that I have listened to of any game, and the visual style I enjoyed a lot.
It plays a lot like a standard RPG, but it also has some added elements to keep it fun and fresh compared to other games.
The story is very well written and holds a lot of value in the subtle meanings behind everything, I found myself thinking about this game for a while after I played it about the little details and meaning behind things.
I played it almost three times getting all the achievements and the first playthrough i did completely blind took me about 25 hours alone, which makes sense for the type of game it is.
I think its very much worth the price its listed at, given how much you get from this game from it being a game as well as an experience overall, and not to mention the time to complete one playthrough and all the content it has being much more than other games of the price.
10/10 masterpiece for me.

130510205.review:
[h1]Omori - an emotional masterpiece[/h1]

Do you love psychological horror? Are you a fan of JRPG/RPG genre? Have you ever wanted a game to make you cry? If you said yes to all three of these questions, look no further, you found a perfect game for you - Omori. [b][u]UNLESS[/u][/b] you are depressed and/or suicidal, then maybe you should play it another time, because this piece of multimedia won't do any good to your condition or it may even worsen it.

I played this game via family sharing but as soon as I finished it I bought the game to support the creators, and also, among other things, to write this review. That's how great the game is and deservedly so.


Omori is a RPG psychological horror with turn-based combat. You take control of the same named character, in a seemingly strange place called White Space, in which the only colors are black and white. You are all alone, with a few items next to you - a laptop, a sketchbook, a box of tissues and a black cat. Above you there is a a light bulb which is pitch black inside. This very setting of the game should give you at least a glimpse about the tone and what you should expect from this game. You exit through the door and meet your 4 best friends - Kel, Hero and Aubrey and you are about to begin your adventure, which will be a roller coaster of many events and emotions.

The world you are about to explore is quite ambiguous and unpredictable, as is the main story. Be prepared to experience a whole range of feelings - happiness, sadness, despair, fear, anguish, anger, loneliness and much more. Also be prepared for A LOT of dialogue, because well, it is a RPG and there's so many NPCs and environments that you can interact with, so be sure that you explore as much as you can. 

The gameplay is fluid and got me hooked right off the bat. I think I finished the game in 30 hours and playing for 10-11 days. You can dodge most of the enemies that are wandering around the map if you want to, but then you risk losing some valuable XP that can help you level your characters which lets them learn a new skill move. Those will be really useful against bosses, so you don't wanna miss that. The bosses in this game can be really easy or a real pain in the ass. I think I got game over screen 2-3 times but whatever, the combat isn't what the game is known for anyway. 

Graphics - it's a classic JRPG pixel vibe with drawn cutscenes which are amazingly done. When you compare the announcement trailer and the end product, you'll realize how much the art has improved. The scary moments and jumpscares are nicely done and are not cheesy as in some cliche horror movie. I actually got really scared quite a few times, so the horror aspect is perfectly done. 

The only thing I could complain about is the rather long playtime, and I think it could have been shortened, but then again, when you take into account how immersive the game is and all the details that you can easily miss, you can only applaud Omocat for their incredible effort. Six and a half years in development ain't no joke for an INDIE game, so kudos to them.

In my opinion, this game is an heir to the throne of Silent Hill 2 - my favorite game ever, and probably one of the most important and greatest games ever made. Both games should be considered as greatest games in that specific genre about personal horror and trauma. These types of games - they are more than a game. They are on a borderline of art-forms and should be greatly appreciated. The greatest con of these games is that once you play and finish them, you'll never be able to relive them for the first time. And on top of that, they have high replay value, which is really impressive. 

(Spoilers about Omori and Silent Hill 2 ahead) [spoiler] The parallels between these 2 games are unreal, and I'm actually amazed that I saw very little comparisons of these two on the internet. Because the original motives of these stories are the same at the root, which is a great sin (murder) committed and remorse after it, the only difference is that on one side are spouses and on the other are siblings. Also the character development is identical - the protagonist rejects the truth and has dissociative amnesia, remembers the whole truth, then faces it and chooses what to do with his life after that, depending on the player's decisions during the game. There are A LOT more similarities but I think the point I'm trying to make is clear.  [/spoiler]

The ending of this game ALMOST made me cry. My eyes teared up and I was really close, but I did not succumb ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°). But this is only because movies and games never made me cry - the only other time I teared up was when I finished the Lord of the Rings movie trilogy, so yeah, the feeling isn't the same and you'll see why.

To sum it all up, Omori is one of the best and most emotional games I ever played. It deserves to go down in history as one of the best games ever made. You don't need fancy graphics and multiplayer with DLCs and other crap to make a masterpiece, and Omori is real proof of that.

128087165.review:
this has quickly become one of if not my favourite game of all time. i heard a lot about omori before i decided to pick it up, and i was even familiar with the artist (omocat) for actually way before i heard anything about the game - buying a bunch of their stuff since way back in 2016. so naturally when i heard they'd made a game it came as a bit of a shock, but i've never been much into RPGs or anything like it so i put it off, until i decided to just give it a shot a couple years past release.

and my god, this game is just about flawless. from start to finish. everything from the art style, the storytelling and character building, to even the combat and entire soundtrack, is carried with so much care and finesse, it actually still blows my mind just thinking about how much of it is pulled off so perfectly. it has i think a few minor flaws and stumbles a bit as it makes its way toward the finish line [spoiler](particularly when it comes to the good ending)[/spoiler] but it's very minor stuff all things considered.

long story short, with as little spoiling as possible, this is an absolute must play. my first playthrough took me a full 24 hours of playtime, but i was doing a bunch of side-content, reading every bit of dialogue, and struggled a bit on a few bosses. which i'd entirely recommend doing as the side content is so charming and fun to do and figure out. but you could just as easily breeze through the game in i'd say about 18-19 hours maybe less if you were insistent on finishing it asap, but this game at least in my opinion, deserves your time.

[b]TL;DR[/b] this game is an indie masterpiece. it will make you cry at certain points and you will so easily fall in love with the characters and this lovely world that omocat and her team has created.

124504764.review:
Omori is a game everyone should play, but not a game for everyone.

Yes, it is a horror game, and tackles some heavy themes, but the game is unique in how it approaches these subjects. Eighty-percent of the game is lighthearted (Deltarune-esque), while the rest is extremely morbid and bizarre.

I enjoyed the story of Omori greatly, though I did often become frustrated with the medium in which it was told. As I played the game, I tended to feel more like a victim of the story than the master of it. This is especially true if you make the mistake of naming the character after yourself (like I did). The powerlessness fits the tone and context, but at the expense of the player’s influence over the narrative. Essentially, try not to go into this game believing your choices are paramount.

The ending of the game left me shocked, curious, frustrated, and (unsurprisingly) depressed. I warn you that getting too invested in this game can be dangerous for the soul. This is a long game, and is best played at your own pace. But if you have the time, it’s definitely worth it.

145940805.review:
There's no kinda story I love more than redemption stories... As a matter of fact, they are a necessity to remind individuals such as myself to forgive ourselves, trust ourselves, love ourselves and simply remember that our mistakes, imperfections and scars don't define the rest of our lives and who we are. To be able to deliver such strong messages is no easy task, but Omori just nails it splendidly; Although this game starts its storytelling process with a bang and there's lots of tension, mystery and suspension there right from the beginning, Omori takes it time beautifully to build everything up and prepare you for one of the most gut-wrenching endings in video games history. The shift between the tones of the more lighthearted parts of the game and the bleak and scary parts is the magic of the storytelling of Omori. Yes, all the sweet details here and there and the metaphorical and environmental storytelling is great, but what makes Omori unforgettable is the hard hitting dose of protagonist's real life in contrast of all the cute moments in Omori's universe or all the funny interactions between the gang... It just gets you.
Not wanting to give away much about the story, let's move on to the gameplay! There's a lot to unpack here! There's this unique and interesting take on jrpg's turned based combat style in which offers you some new mechanics that are really fun to play around with. At the beginning of the game, the combat might seem a little confusing to the players who are not that familiar with turned based combat systems, but there's no need to worry cause the game does a great job at explaining the mechanics to the player. Just remember that if you want the combat to remains challenging. avoid grinding... Specially at Orange Oasis' Pyramid; You can just fly to the maximum level there. Aside from the combat there are many of puzzles and some mini games to keep things fresh and more fun, but not all of them are right there in front of you; Keep an eye open for these rewarding experiences.
AND what can I say about the gorgeous eye candy art-style and character design of Omori that hasn't been said thousands of times before? The visuals are one of the two most important selling points of this game. You just gotta see everything for yourself. 
Overall, Yeah, I totally recommend this game. It's truly one of the best gaming experiences I ever had. Looking forward to whatever Omocat is gonna do next!

137930940.review:
After nearly a year since I last played OMORI, I’ve realized that this is how a game should handle a subject such as childhood trauma. From its ability to still remain somber with its subject material & still have enough side content to not be overly depressing. Its somewhat crude-hand drawn style accompanied with its music is what I feel makes this game timeless, especially with it somewhat reminding of my own childhood. The music especially, as it is somehow able to match also any part of the game perfectly, while still remaining strong just by itself. I find this to be especially apparent with the boss & faraway songs, all of which go so much harder than they have any right to. 

The first day Sunny awakes from his bed is one of the best ways of introducing a passage of time, as everything before that was previously introduced about the main characters is immediately flipped on its head (aside from Kel). Especially with Aubrey, as she goes into a violent emotional wreck, while starting off as the exact opposite. As almost any character traits previously held in Headspace are no longer present when Sunny exits his house for the first time. With the game’s lack of flashbacks & almost pure reliance on dialogue setting up the previous character traits naturally. This creates a feeling I find barely any games or other forms of media are able to recreate.
Every single main character I find has enough details to make you invested in them, without having to give off an entire backstory to accomplish it. Even many of the side characters, (primarily in Aubrey’s gang) also have enough traits to separate them from just a generic NPC. Even with characters like Hero, which would be considered 1 dimensional with how they're written in the past & somewhat in the present, is eventually given more character clues if you go looking for them. This all comes together to create an atmosphere that truly parrales & is applicable to almost anyone's life in one form or another. 

(SPOILERS) I find the way the antagonist SOMETHING is written perfectly represents how both Basil & Sunny view their trauma. From his appearances being little more than a simple puzzle, with it being hard for them to kill you without a lot of time devoted, & yet both Sunny and Basil still fear it. This shows how, while he may not be much of a threat, he still manages to influence their actions, especially in the end of the good route. 
The only parts which I didn't feel held up to the standard set by every other part, are things like Black Space & a bit of the horror. Manly because I find its set pieces to be too confusing to be able to tie it back to the main game. The only exception to this I feel is the Stranger, as they outright tell you what each one might represent. 

(SPOILERS) the way each route ends & the endings themselves are all unique in the ways you can accomplish them (excluding the good ending). The fact that going the Hikikomori route results in the same amount of gameplay content as the Sunny route, is something I’ve never seen in any other game I’ve played. This is especially unique as only about 7.1% of the player base has ever seen the end to the Hikikomori route. The way the Sunny route ends with a flashback through every single memory present in the photo book, & to eventually leave it open-ended while still feeling satisfied is truly an achievement. The fact that you can see the consequences of your actions before this I feel is also something that complements the Hikikomori route, as you see what happens if you don’t save Basil, & choose to live in constant apathy.

Ultimately, the fact that OMOCAT was able to jam this much detail into a game that takes little more than 20 hours to beat is something that I feel should be followed by many others. This is because I feel that  quantity over quality is something that is being somewhat forgotten in many of the big studios’ stories. Combine this with the fact that this entire game was created in RPG maker of all things, just goes to show how it doesn’t take much to convey a truly captivating story. 

	All of these things is why this game has pervaded in my mind for almost a year, as my mind is unable to stop thinking about it even today. From the story, to the characters, & especially the setting & theming, it has never failed to be something I would call a masterpiece.


P.S, If you read through all of this, thanks :)

132500500.review:
Not sure what I can say without spoiling the game, except that playing it both affected and touched me deeply, to the point where it's still fresh and dear to me after playing it back in early 2021.

Don't want to sound pretentious or profound or anything, but I like to think that this game has changed me for the better.

Please, if you can, go into this game as blind as you can(not in the literal sense of course). It might feel a bit slow and ponderous in some cases like in the beginning, but it's worth the time.

If it's not for you, then that's perfectly understandable, but all I ask is you give it a chance and some time.

If you like undertale, you'll LOVE Omori.

This game kept me invested throughout its entirety, with an ending you just can't forget.
I recommend it to pretty much everyone.

130238759.review:
I love this game so much, from the story to the character arcs, everything is perfect <3

Worth the price, I love the characters so so so much their all so relatable in so many ways, this game left me broken I swear it took half of my heart I've cried so much over this game. Beautiful, the main characters are presented so well. They all have such personalities. The detail is crazy, the side quests are so cute. Both routes (Omori and Sunny) have such good plots - 

Not to mention all the bosses are perfect, I adore their personalities. Spaceboys grief, sweethearts entire personality, and the slime girls are just majestic. I love the enemies so much- Their personalities are so different In the best way possible.

There's nothing I don't like in this game. Brought tears to my eyes 10/10.

130211831.review: I've played a lot of games in my life but very few have the heart and passion that Omori has. A love letter to Yume Nikki, the pixel art and general art design of this game are extraordinary!! The soundtrack is one of the best in recent memory for me too, filled with so many different influences. It's clear a lot of effort was put into every detail to the game, down to its obscure secrets and hidden areas. I'll admit, sometimes the game does suffer from some pacing issues, certain parts lingering for longer than they should but... that doesn't stop it from being an amazing experience. Grateful for games like these :)

129988155.review: When starting out with this game, I assumed it would be just like Undertale or Deltarune, except a little more scary, or deep. Boy i was wrong. When i started getting invested into this game, the story really felt real and i felt like i could feel empathy for the characters in the story. The ending of the game was especially emotional for me. Looking through and placing Mari's photos in the album while her piano plays in the background really made me cry. I had felt something in a video game that most people would consider cringe or stupid, that I was sad for the situations. I really wanted to root for Sunny (especially since I will NEVER play the omori route) and i felt like I was really making a change. When I had completed the game, I actually felt accomplished, something I had not felt in a video game for years. Please play this game and recommend it to your friends. If the amazing unique art style and music choice doesn't capture you then I'm sure the story will.

125318987.review:
from a gameplay standpoint i think its pretty fine but nothing super amazing or anything, your average jrpg. the emotion and follow-up mechanics were p cool. it was pretty easy but that was probably cause i was going for a completionist run and overgrinded. some of the headspace sections did feel like a bit of a slog at times (like sweetheart's castle which felt like it went on and on) but it was nothing frustrating to deal with. theres a ton of secrets you could easily miss with how the game never points them out to you, im pretty sure i didnt get everything even w how much i looked. so theres a lot to uncover if you like discovering stuff but its kinda annoying when you find out you missed something important.

storywise? god. the themes this game deals with are so fucking heavy but it handles them w care and balances it out w other messages the game conveys. tragedy and suffering is a constant in our life, but so is the hope that things will get better, and that no matter what, you'll always have someone to depend on no matter how hard or awful things get. it sounds kinda cheesy and cliche but friendship is a huge message this game delivers: friends should stick together no matter what and be there for each other when they need it the most. i dont think ive ever cared for a cast of characters this much. you see what this tight knit group of friends go through and how it changes who they are as people. you want to protect them and see them recover and make it through and!! man if that isnt the best feeling in the world when they do. it probably isnt the most healthy realization but i relate a lot to what some characters deal with, especially sunny's internal conflicts.

all in all, omori was a game that took my heart out, stomped on it, called it a bitch, felt bad about what it done, apologized, then took it out for a nice steak dinner. the journey had its major ups and down but its all worth it in the end. like,, Fuck. i am never gonna forget this game.

There were times when i got really bored especially when running into passable npcs and doing minor quests but i think overall that's it(?). 123921401.review:
To attempt to describe this game, and my feelings for it, in a short paragraph of review would be doing both a disservice. But, regardless, that is what I am here to do. Omori is a game about a lot of things; it's about friendship and drifting apart, loss and love. It is a game that will suck you into it, as much through it's immense charm and humor as through its plot and more personal moments. No matter where you are at in the game, no matter what you are doing, this is a game that's going to make you feel something. Whether that be ecstasy, depression, or something in between will heavily depend on where you are, but you will be feeling some strong emotions during this game and for that feat, I heartily recommend it. 

All it costs is your love (plus $20)

132297546.review:
A splendid experience.
   Playing this masterpiece feels like a bittersweet dream that could never end if you chose to. An infinite perfect world of imaginary friends and foes. And while this bliss sure is colorful and joyful, there's still something lurking behind the scenes. SOMETHING that's always by your side. SOMETHING that you desperately try to forget, but SOMETHING that always finds a way to come back. SOMETHING you've been living with for too long.
   What is the solution? Would you rather face the reality, or stay in this lullaby? What are you willing to do? Are you just going to stay here, waiting for something to happen?


For more details, read the following paragraphs :

   In general, the art direction of this game is astonishing. The mix of pixel art and sketchy-like style is simply wonderful. The color palette is amazing too. It has been a real pleasure the whole time; and sometimes there are great surprises, but hey! no spoil!

   The combat mechanics are really clever too ; the EMOTIONS add so much life and character to the fights. Furthermore, when we're brought to brawl a lot, our group levels up. But this isn't just a matter of numbers that increase; besides that, the personalities of the characters have a more direct impact during the fights! The more the members of your group will fight, the more they will be able to work together, by increasing their stats, changing their emotions, attacking twice, encouraging each other... we trully feel an exchange between their person, and it's not a regular combat mechanic that we see in video games.

   And last but certainly not least, the story. The main plot is quite intriguing and becomes more and more interesting as you play the game. I don't want to spoil, so I just ask you to play it to understand what I am talking about!

You won't regret it. And remember.

It's not as scary as you think.

132231029.review: Fantastic game. It's got a compelling narrative (if not a litttleee over-barring occasionally) and very interesting gameplay. I do have 1 problem with this game however, if you're looking for rich, complex, strategic gameplay look elsewhere. You play as a team of 4, Omori, Aubrey, Hero, and Kel, each of them have their own quirks, skills, and traits. The problem I have with this game is that since Omori is the main character, when he's knocked down, everyone is knocked down. And this to me is a game breaker in a turn based RPG. Your team is not equal. Don't go in trying to play your own way, because eventually you end up just guarding Omori for 90% of the combat because even though your whole team is thriving and winning, you could get unlucky and have the enemy target Omori once or twice because it's random and that's just it. He's dead, you're all dead. It has to be one of the lamest mechanics I've ever seen in a strategy game and it holds the game back so much for me. If you want compelling narrative combined with "okay" gameplay, this ones for you. If you want deep strategy look elsewhere.

130342849.review:
If you like story and have not been spoiled yet then this is great [strike] (but you could also watch a playthrough for free!). [/strike] As for combat, the emotion system is creative, though everything else is basically the default RPGmaker template. It's also really easy (I may be biased). I solved this by self imposed challenges which makes it surprisingly fun actually. 

This game is FAR from perfect, here's a list of things that annoyed me:
- A ton of minor bugs and a few more that are a bit major
- Most cutscenes are unskippable
- 100%ing the game requires multiple playthroughs
- Overworld healing is only possible by using items or picnics that are very sparsely placed
- Running away from encounters is not guaranteed
- 6 saveslots may not be enough for some (like me)

Thankfully, a lot of these problems are solved because of the massive modding community, there's a ton of quality of life mods to make the game more enjoyable, I suggest using these [b] immediately [/b] even at the first playthrough. Bug fix mods are a bit limited right now because of the sheer number of bugs and the fact that fixing some of them is an absolute nightmare (trust me i tried). If you wish, there are a lot of mods that also help make the game more challenging either through making more crazy challenge runs possible or new bosses.

Despite everything, it's a good game, worth to get at a discount especially with all the mods available 👍
Don't play it for 400 hours though

142965558.review:
No content spoilers in this, but probably still best not to read if you intend on playing this.

I really enjoyed this but I think the ending overshadowed how I actually felt about this game. Throughout most of it it felt like there was an interesting story that you were trying to piece together, but honestly, the game never gave you any pieces to work with. It kept kind of dangling the same vague clue in front of your face over and over and it never really made sense, until it kind of all hit at the end. Sure, that made the end even more impactful, but it doesn't distract from the fact that the storytelling in 90% of the game was somewhat lackluster. It was engaging and fun, but it did not actually achieve or progress anything. But maybe I was just too dumb to piece all the clues together in my mind, so this might not be an issue for others.

The combat was also kinda eh? It was satisfying but mostly because it was easy, I literally did not die once in this game with minimal grinding and I am *not* good at these sorts of games, when I played the mother games I died countless times. I also entirely disregarded emotions and went full offense with all my skills and equipment, and I still never had a problem. The music and cool enemies kinda made up for it but it really could have been a little bit harder. The equipment is also pretty annoying, there's tons that do almost the same thing but with different emotions and it's really hard to actually figure out what you want for who and why, and a ton of the skills literally just say "does some damage" and I personally had absolutely no motivation to stray from my couple good ones to risk trying those out.

Overall it was a really great experience and I enjoyed it a whole lot, the music is amazing as well, but it certainly has its flaws that keep it from being my favorite.

124552221.review:
First of all, do not go into this game expecting a "terrifying psychological horror game" or a spiritual successor to classic RPGMaker horror games. Despite how many fans proclaim the horror elements are VASTLY overstated.

The combat feels surprisingly good and sets itself apart general RPGMaker games. I didn't experience a need to grind XP and the difficulty felt fair.

My main complaints are that it does feel somewhat overly long (20 hours is quite much for an RPGMaker game). Many sections overstay their welcome and certain dungeons feel kind of like a drag. A lot of the humor didn't land. Apart from one subtle scene regarding a character's background, the game didn't really manage to pull my heartstrings.

The story is mostly entertaining and keeps you guessing. Despite some major plot holes the ending wraps up the game nicely and makes up for some earlier dragging parts. Overall a mostly positive experience as long as you're patient to get past the slower parts.
7.5/10

Edit: Oh and before you may think "You're just not the intended demographic, you don't have the past or perspective required to relate to the story's subject matters"- nope, the touched issues should be right up my alley but just didn't feel impactful or "genuine". Something about touting around depictions of trauma feels hollow and "wrong" to me, like a major part is just edginess and wanting praise for discussing the topics. Of course if you were touched and moved by them all the good to you.

130880894.review: "Quirky Earthbound-Inspired Indie Game About Depression" might describe OMORI on the surface, but it's cruel to reduce it to such a silly title.
