145495606.review:
I don't know where to begin or how to end this, but I've been thinking about writing something for this game for a long time but just never came around to it. It's difficult to explain the wide range of emotions I experienced throughout my playthrough, because it made me think and reminisce about everything that has ever been in my life thus far. I consider myself a person that is never truthful about how he truly feels and someone who never shares their feelings and thoughts, I am someone who doesn't cry in front of others and never complains about how bad it is, and that's fine because that's just the way I had to grow up to survive.

I've never played a video game that has made me just sit back and [b] really [/b] think about everything that has led me up to this point in time. Many memories resurfaced again, it made me think about the childhood that I never had, friends that I could never get, things I never got to experience, about someone that was special to me, and about people that have long left the world. 

It all made me realize how truly miserable I feel, because I've always believed that I was numb to everything, but the reality is that I was feeling so much to the point where I've had to subconsciously numb myself to run away from it. I think the reason the game resonated so much with me is because I saw myself in Sunny, because we aren't really that different, we both locked ourselves away and shut out the whole world in order to protect ourselves and cope with the pain.

Throughout the game while playing as Sunny, I was trying to right his wrongs and guide him down a better path, because in a way it felt like I was trying to fix my younger self while also making sure that Sunny doesn't end up the way I did. I've felt constant anguish ever since finishing the game and even now while writing this wall of text I still feel the same. I cannot help but think about the past that could've been and wishing that things could've gone differently. 

People always talk about seeing the light at the end of the tunnel and how things get better, but my approach to life has always been to just try and be comfortable living in the dark, because it doesn't get better. But if there was a way to start life all over again then I would gladly take that chance, the things I would give just to be able to go back and have the things that I never got, like being a kid and have a chance at a normal life while being surrounded with love and having tons of friends to hangout with without having a single care in the world. 

But it's too late for that.



No other game comes close to what this one made me feel, it's easily deserving of a 10/10.

136691500.review: While I'm not as enthusiastic as some reviewers, I certainly can't fault the game and felt it was pretty good. The gameplay sadly doesnt build on Undertale's innovations in turn based combat, so its entirely the boring pokemon-style system. Aesthetically I persistently wished the horror elements would go a bit harder then they ever reached, with the imagery for the most part retaining a child-appropriate cartoonishness to it that softened the blow and always left me a little underwhelmed. While Earthbound and Yume Nikki are the obvious points of comparison, the game has a lot in common with last year's title Signalis, with both approaching themes of loss and dreaming, albeit with very different methods (that both carry obvious Silent Hill 2 influence adds something of a common origin to both). Between the two games, I prefered Signalis' imagery and leitmotifs moreso than Omori's, as it accomplished that harder edge that I was hoping for in Omori. Story wise however neither perfectly manage what they set out to do; as where Signalis' story was told too obliquely as to be confusing, Omori has the opposite problem of coming off much too direct in its messages as to become didactic. All in all though I enjoyed playing it and felt my appreciation of both games were strengthened when read as companion-pieces to each other despite their differences. Each game, while flawed in a number of ways, are enjoyably meaningful and engaging works of art.

In a medium bowl, whisk together dry ingredients: flour, baking powder, and salt.
In a second bowl (or bowl of your stand mixer), beat together softened butter and sugar on medium-high speed 5 minutes until thick and fluffy.
Beat in eggs 1 at a time, mixing to incorporate with each egg then blend in vanilla and scrape down the bowl.
Reduce mixer to medium speed and add the flour in thirds, alternating with adding the 1/2 cup buttermilk and beating well between additions.
Pour batter into 12 lined muffin tins, filling 2/3 full. Bake in the center of the oven at 350˚F for 20-23 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean. Let cool 5 minutes in the pan then remove cupcakes to a wire rack to cool completely.

124399240.review:
This was by far the most memorable experience I have ever had with a video game, and is the strongest example of video games counting as art that I can think of (at least from what I've played). Made me cry like four times, and the story stuck with me so hard that I'm here buying the game again and writing a review nearly a year after my initial playthrough. This is the kind of game that I expect -- and hope -- aspiring developers will take inspiration from going forward.

It's worth noting that despite the game being tagged as psychological horror, the horror depicted in this game is unsettling rather than scary. It's tastefully done, relies minimally on jumpscares (I think I had maybe two mild ones in my entire playthrough), and the "horror" sections are really interesting to play through. If you're off-put by the horror tag because you don't like scary stuff, this game is probably still fine for you.

If you are able to handle the content that's described in the content warning, play this game. It is easily worth the asking price and will stick with you long after you've finished playing it (especially considering the OST is on Spotify).

146012185.review:
Such a good game i had to write my own review for the first time! (a lengthy one for anyone interested in the opinion of strangers)

->P L O T
The player assumes the role of Omori, the alter ego of a teenager. The world is split in two sides: Faraway Town represents reality, while HeadSpace (as the name suggests) is an imaginary place, Omori's escape from reality. The story follows Omori and his friends on their journey to find someone missing, oscillating back to the teenager's reality and so forth. The main themes and motives include friendship, family, grief, redemption, anxiety, depression, suicide ( and many others ofc). 

As a depressed fellow myself, there were many aspects of the story I related to on a deeply personal level. Regardless, I find that the story can be appealing to just about anyone, as it is a wonderful mix between wholesome and disturbing( on a psychological level). OMORI combines joy and sorrow, tangling these two polar concepts successfully!

( TLDR: This game will heal your poor little heart and then stomp on it with no hesitation. Then heal it again and repeat the process. You will ugly cry for hours)

-> G A M E P L A Y
The lengthyyyyyyyyyyyy duration of the game is no worry as it keeps the player entertained with lots of fun and exciting mini side quests (optional) , as well as diverse foes (some cuter than others) to challenge using your own skills, weapons, charms and so on. Grinding is possible but definitely not necessary to advance. Difficulty is easy to medium, any foe can be defeated with a bit of planning and strategy, if none at all,  in this humble stranger's opinion. Even after finishing the game, I intend to play again knowing there are still loooooooooots of things to do and discover.

(TLDR: Very fun, will keep u constantly entertained. Friendly for noobs like myself)

->G R A P H I C S
Stunning. Fantastic. Amazing. Spectacular. Marvelous. Splendid. Excellent.
I was captivated by the charming 8 bit pixel style, as well as the hand drawn sketchbook visuals. Wonderful use of colors (or lack of when necessary). 

(TLDR: Pretty af)

-> M U S I C
The soundtrack of OMORI has become my favorite after finishing the game. It has everything from catchy playful tunes to heartbreaking sounds of piano and violin. I find it hard to describe music with words, but in terms of feelings the soundtracks adjusted to them accordingly. I have never felt so disturbed by ominous and eerie music before. It makes you feel....the sound of emptiness. Of course, heartwarming joy, happiness, or relief is also present when needed.

(TLDR: It's like a shawarma with everything. That everything being every emotion on the spectrum)

-> P R I C E 
Maybe not the most student friendly at first, but after playing, I can proudly say that i would use my entire life savings on this game if I could. Omocat, please take all my peasant money.

->C O N C L U S I O N S
Overall, this game was a 10/10 for me, I have nothing but praise for the work put into it. 
It is heavy mentally, so I advise being careful before playing. It triggered unpleasant memories in me, but even so, OMORI has a special place in my heart after such an impact. It was really wholesome and funny, bringing a smile to my face while playing. There is a high probability that the game will change your perspective in life. Thank you, OMORI, for showing such raw, pure, nostalgic and infantile emotions to me, taking me back to an uncensored past and back again in the reality where my life goes on, but grows from every memory I have created. 

And THANK YOU, kind reader, for reaching the end of my review. I wish I could re experience OMORI, but I hope you have/had as much of a special experience with this game as I did :) .

P.S. I strongly advise you to have a couple packs of tissues prepared before playing. Have fun dear <3

141924368.review:
So I'll come out front and say I consider this my favorite game of all time. That's not to say it's a perfect game, but rather it has a story so cathartic that it's on a level I've never experienced before in gaming or elsewhere. It's a story that I think about regularly, that feels so real and so personal for someone who has experienced anxiety, intrusive thoughts, panic attacks and isolation. It's a genuine message of understanding from OMOCAT to players that have experienced that pain, and it hits me particularly right in the heart. It's sad, it's painful, it's lonely, it's scary, but there is comfort and support in the end. 

Everything I talk about going forward is for the "true" route, the other route should only be played after experiencing the game normally.

I do have nitpicks that I want to get out of the way first. There are pacing issues, especially in some of the midgame Headspace segments. Headspace is basically OMORI's dream world, it's where you spend most of the game and it's also where you go through dungeons, solve puzzles and fight battles. There's very little advancing of the plot for most of these bits. Lotta cute character moments, but I know many people give up in these parts because they just want to uncover the elusive backstory or continue the plot. It's a huge shame, because the final stretch of this game serves as a sort of narrative key that recontextualizes those slow moments. It all comes together in a beautiful way in the end, if you're patient. Like, 25+ hours patient.

To remedy this, I recommend skipping as many battles as you can. The game has a weird level scaling issue where the early game is quite challenging, but if you fight everything along your way, the late game becomes mind-numbingly easy. So just run from as many battles as you can, it helps speed up the slow pace of the dungeons *and* keeps the late game challenging, but doable.

On the subject of combat. As a fan of turn-based RPGs (maybe my moogle avatar tipped that one off) I think fights are incredibly fun!! The emotion system is genuinely a unique mechanic that I've not really seen before, basically merging status effects and elemental affinities into a single system. You'll have access to dozens of skills with your 4 characters that can change your and your enemies' emotional states, provide buffs, and of course if you use your noggin, land massively powerful blows! You can also use well-timed follow-up skills while battle animations are taking place, letting you add powerful moves on-the-fly. You could tell HERO heal someone after the enemy lands a crit, or just spam OMORI's Attack Again to add extra damage. Balancing this stuff is incredibly fun and engaging from beginning to end, and your list of options is always expanding rapidly, keeping things fresh. 

Back to the story, something that's important to know going into the game (besides all the very important content warnings!) is that the game has a HUGE range of tones. Saccharine, melodramatic, horrific— I like to think of the way OMORI does this as a mash-up between 3 specific games. Paper Mario for the saccharine bits in the dreamworld, Mother 3 for the dramatic bits in the real world, and Yume Nikki for the horrific and surreal segments sprinkled across both. The early game is very heavy on the saccharine which... I can understand if you're not that into it. It might not be what you thought you were getting into. Stick with it, please! The dynamic between these different tones is important and intended, and like I said earlier, builds up to something amazing.

So what does it build up to, exactly? Well, I want to keep the spoilers to a minimum so I'm going to try to stick to describing the opening and then the ~vibe~ of the game. The game starts in what is actually the middle of the story. Sort of a hero-at-his-lowest-point moment. Something awful has happened and the character you control has given up on life. You don't want to leave your house, you don't want to leave your bed, all your anxieties that used to be minor hurdles for you have magnified themselves to such a degree that even being awake makes your mind run with constant fear and paranoia. You've ghosted your friends for so long that your memories of them are fading. You're hallucinating. No one is helping you. And it's getting worse. You have nothing but a carefully constructed world in your dreams entirely built out of nostalgic childhood memories. Is even this dream world going to last?

So not off to a great start are we? I'll be real, it's fucking hard. It's a struggle seeing some of yourself in the main character. Again, content warnings, but he will lead you down a dark path. But... it's not hopeless. It never really was, was it? In the end, that isolation was self-imposed, it was not forced on our character. Connection is possible, if just barely. Can you face your fears, and accept a helping hand when it comes?

There is SO MUCH to this game, it was so carefully and lovingly crafted. I hope I've piqued your interest, because maybe this game will have as much of an impact on you as it had on me. Personally, I'm very glad I had the chance for it to be a part of my life.

139454661.review:
Aight so I got some THINGS to say. Lots of good, lots of bad. The whole game is split up into two segments. To avoid spoilers I'll call them the gameplay section and the story section, cause that's what they are. The gameplay section gives you lots of random quests and has you fight enemies in typically rpg fashion. It reminds me very much of pokemon combat except with fewer "types" and types can be adjusted mid battle.  Pretty cool concept honestly.

For the story section, it's mostly the same thing but with way, way more optional quests to do and way less combat. I won't talk about the story much, but it explores a lot of heavy stuff as well as a few truly horrifying concepts that I haven't seen talked about anywhere else.

The music is incredible and has some brilliant boss themes. The mood throughout is mostly lots of happy fluff, (though not necessarily a bad thing,) before random bits of your insides being scrambled. My main complaint about the game is honestly that the story was so good and that I was so invested in it, that whenever a gameplay section would show up, I wasn't very eager to continue. They last for way too long and it doesn't feel like you're doing anything important. Definitely a very weak part of the game, especially for me as I have a *lot* of gripes about turn based rpgs, leveling, ect.

=====100%ing the game=====
(minor spoiler warning)
This is definitely far less important than the blind playthrough, but in case anyone wanted to achievement hunt for this game, let me tell you, it isn't fun. Before you do anything, get a program that can make the game run at higher speeds. Like 2-3x faster minimum. There's two routes, with several achievements exclusive to both. I would say to keep *lots* of save files but there's a max of 6. You could copy the saves folder to your desktop or somewhere else to make more if you wanted to though.

Anyhow, most of the achievements are incredibly grindy and very uninteresting. These include watching a 10 second cutscene repeatedly until getting all 11 randomly generated events to happen. Spamming the flee button on enemies to farm trash to give to a recycling machine, following online guides to a tee to make sure you complete multi day long quests that give you no confirmation of having done them correctly, meaning *don't mess up or that'll cost you several hours to fix*, assuming you have saves and know exactly where you messed up.

About half the time I have on this game was achievement grinding, and that really sucks. Definitely the most time I've put into a game that I've felt like I'm not doing anything. If you don't normally like 100%ing games, this should NOT be your intro to it.

139393269.review:
You absolutely need to play this game.
I got it as a gift from a friend, but I absolutely would have paid full price for it.
You won't find a game with better storytelling than OMORI, and it has a fantastic story to tell. It's on my 'must play' list when people ask for game recommendations.
It hits all of the boxes for a fantastic indie game except for one. Some of the fights you encounter could be designed a lot better in my opinion.
I will continue to explain why in the spoiler block. If you haven't played the game knowing anything about it will badly impact your experience. I won't give any spoilers at all, just game mechanics, but this game is best completely blind so continue at your own risk.
[spoiler]
The game has a leveling system where your characters get increases to all your friend's stats. For one of the fights on a second playthrough, omori got knocked out turn one, before I even had the chance to try an attack. I don't have a problem with that on optional fights, but ones that progress the story shouldn't even let you try them if the game thinks you are underleveled. It'd be nice if they added something as simple as making the earlier fights give more exp, or overworld hazards that require higher level abilities to get through.
[/spoiler]
That is literally the only complaint I have about the game. The story telling, the fight mechanics, the character personalities, the humor, the artstyle, and the story itself are not only phenomenal, but exemplary for games in the future.

138475372.review:
I waited until I had unlocked all the achievements (3 playthroughs, 110 hours altogether.  I did not follow a guide or optimized routes, but I think it's realistic to expect 20 - 30 hours for typical playthrough) to write this.  The best way I can describe this game without spoiling it is to say that it starts out with the casual-chaos vibes and vibrant nature akin to Adventure Time or The Adventures of Bee and Puppy Cat but it progresses slowly and seamlessly into horror.  I would definitely recommend.  More importantly, I would definitely recommend going in blind knowing as little about the actual gameplay and story as possible; this review contains no spoilers out of respect for that, so I apologize if it seems mechanical and vague.   

I originally heard of this game because the youtube algorithm recommended a video to me by ThatGuyGlen, which details the controversy surrounding Omori's development and why a lot of people thought it was a scam.  Aside from showing some of the development art and clips from previews (many of which had concepts not used in the game), there's no spoilers in the video if you want to watch it (I would avoid the comment section, though).  What caught my attention is that this was a modern game that was made in the style of an early 90s top-down JRPG, that the graphics were all pixel art or hand drawn(!), and that first-and-formost, Omocat really treated the game itself as an artistic medium; Omori is very much an art project as much or more than it is a game.  The whole package was wild to me, and I had to give it a try. 

I'm glad I did.  The world is amazingly constructed with several unique biomes, literally thousands of objects you can interact with (and some interactions are different depending on who in your party is interacting with them), and the music just...  It fits perfectly with the both the physical environment and emotion of the world and story.  The music also somehow manages to be modern, but doesn't seem out of place for a 90s-era console RPG.  The combat system is good but not great - kinda like if Pokemon would let you have 4 critters out at once.  I wish they had more fights that relied on mechanics to keep things interesting through multiple playthroughs, because it does get a little tedious at times.  I thought the story was fantastic.  While not perfect, I found it very compelling and I appreciate that they keep some things open-ended for you to figure out and connect.  

I have very few, and very small gripes, most of which are more personal preference or QoL.  For example, there are a few cut-scenes that are really single images and they aren't on the screen long enough to enjoy.  I would've liked the option to "push X to continue" or something, as well as a gallery to revisit later.  I wish I could button mash to advance text faster than the game allows.  The menus are intuitive, but can be cumbersome (especially inventory, and especially inventory during combat).  

At the end of the day, I wholeheartedly recommend.  I recommend a blind playthrough if you haven't been spoiled yet, and at the very least a second playthrough.  My second (and third) times through, I noticed so many details connected to the story that just didn't register the first time through.  Actually, I had even forgotten about those details until I played again.  The devs really put a lot of care and attention to detail in the game, and it shows.

138222110.review:
For the last 8 years of my life, UNDERTALE was the standard of a video game. It was a masterpiece, in my mind, that would never be passed.

Then I played OMORI.

This is the game. There have been games I have cried on, that I have been mad at, that I have been ECSTATIC playing, and that have made me genuinely terrified.

None of them have done all four. Before Omori.

The story is easily the greatest I have ever played. The callbacks and writing are amazing. The characters make you invested in them early on, and it stays there. One of my most anticipated story lines begins early in the game and doesn't finish until one of the last segments. 

The twists are never seen coming, yet feel obvious after the fact. They are truly one of the most impactful things about this game.

This game also is an RPG that has plenty of memorable and funny enemies, I remember I particularly started laughing at one enemy in game for a solid 10 minutes. 

This game could have easily, and legitimately, been Mother 4 and I would not have batted an eye. That's high praise.

OMORI is my favourite game of all time, it could be yours as well.

138164220.review:
Overall, while Omori is a good game, it didn't manage to make me forget I'm playing an RPG maker game. There's a lot of friction ! Not like I'm against a game having friction or taking its time, but it didn't seem justified here.

The turn based combat have interesting mechanics, the emotion system is nothing groundbreaking but works really well and fits within the theme of the game nicely, but it feels really sluggish, the time between animations and at the end of a fight really dragged everything down.
Dialogues are often long and can't be skipped in a meaningful way, it's particularly bad if you consider that you can basically miss a good half of the game pretty early and it makes replaying the parts you already went through pretty annoying.
Same thing for some cutscenes that can't be skipped (like the ones where you enter a new zone with a sloooooow travelling camera across the area).

That being said, I love the art direction, the wobbly characters and cute enemies in combats, the varied environments in headspace and the colors used to depict it, making it very dreamy... Cool music too.
I liked the story too, not quite at the level I expected with so many people raving about it but it was still quite good and had some very heartfelt moment. I wouldn't say it touched me that much but if you're dealing with guilt, it might fall closer to home for you.

I would recommend Omori if you're interested in its themes.
Also little tip if you don't wanna miss half of the game the first time around : when your friend come banging at your door, you REALLY should open to him !

138163072.review:
I don't make game reviews but I'm bored and I'm on steam so I will

OMORI as a game is amazing, the battle mechanics utilizing emotions is interesting and always allows the battles to be fresh, especially due to the fact that with certain Items you can boost the speed of party members to allow for different attack orders. Move's learned by the party are interesting as well, although the main cast all has clear things they're very good at. Hero being the healer and tank for the most part, Aubrey being able to dish out a ton of damage, and Kel being an extremely fast and useful party member being able to do both healing and high damage fast but being able to become TOAST just as fast. (Although they're jobs are insinuated via their skills you can for the most part choose how you'd like to use them for your play through.)

The story and characters are the main reason I'd recommend this game to anyone willing to give it a go. The game talks on topics most wouldn't like to share and does an amazing job at it, in my opinion all the characters are very unique and have an amazing charm to them, bosses included. The art style adding even more onto the charm of the characters being very bright and cutesy at face value but can also get dark and serious when needed.

The world is easy to get sucked into the colors are bright and the characters along with the bosses are drawn amazingly, each area has a clear difference and never really gets too boring. It allows for the freshness of the first area to be carried over to the following areas, unlocking new things to do and access overtime rewarding the player if they were to backtrack to previous areas where they couldn't do such things with items to equip and use later in the story.

My only real problem with the game is mainly the pacing towards the end. Once you get to a certain part of the game you want to do less exploring and just get to the "bread and butter" of the story (which at least for me in my first play through) made me opt out on A LOT of quests and things to do if I WERE to explore the world instead of moving forward with the game. (on my most recent replay of the game though I made sure I did as much quests as possible and explore as much as I could which I HIGHLY RECOMMEND YOU DO.)

The pacing towards the end of the game does feel slow but it makes up for it with an amazing soundtrack, art, characters, world, and game play. Even after two play throughs of this game there is STILL more content and story I could learn and find if I were to have another go and play through OMORI once again.

With everything said I hope this review helps you decide on buying or playing OMORI and if you do manage to play I hope you enjoy the game!

137779580.review:
Omori is gonna be one of those games that people cite when they are explaining that video games sometimes aren't just games. 

You play as Omori while asleep and in your head, and as Sunny while awake. Sunny is moving away in three days at the start of the game, and it's clear something is off. You're going to have to find out what by playing the game, but Omori going on adventures will slowly reveal what's going on in Sunny's head. The game plays a little like a JRPG, with a top-down environment when exploring and turn-based combat.

While a lot of similar games feel like a slog because they just a serious story and nothing else, Omori shines in all categories. It'll make you laugh at jokes, love the characters, stare at the art, be impressed with clever character ideas, try-hard in battles, and still tie it all together to be meaningful AND fun in the end. 

You can tell a lot of love went into the creation of Omori and I'd recommend it to just about anyone.

136713519.review:
I pirated this game at first because it interested me. As you can see now I bought the game because for me:

IT IS JUST SO DAMN GOOD.

Considering that this game falls under the same categories of cryptic indie RPG games similar to games like Yume Nikki, UNDERTALE, among others, I was drawn to this game as the trailer showed already an enticing concept of a seemingly whimsical dream world. Playing through this game, I was not only proven wrong, but given a new perspective to mental illnesses and emotional nuance.

Speaking of nuance, I was pleasantly surprised as to how the story functioned, with it not entirely resolving with a one-and-done battling of hearts and minds.
As for the gameplay itself, some people warned that the RPG aspects of the game might get repetitive and/or a bit too easy, and while the latter might be true for what I did when I pirated the first time, the mechanics they use in the battles make me think of strategies that may or may not exist already. They're still fun every single time something does or doesn't go my way. The graphics and art are fitting with the idea of a whimsical dream world, sometimes even contradicting the situation, creating a creepy atmosphere that adds to the weight of the situation. There's a lot of depth with the art here, as it contributes directly to the main story of the game.
I would say that some of the quests are a bit confusing at times, but thankfully, not required to experience the full weight of the game's story. Some people may not like the mechanics of the battles either or the difficulty of it, but for me, it is just chill enough to keep me engaged and wary to strategize. In short, this game is potent in emotion, hits both expected and unexpectedly, and vividly innovative. And that could go unmatched for some time. Not to mention the absolutely cheery yet depressing soundtrack, hell yeah.

A 10.

136361263.review:
(TL;DR) Just buy it and play it blind, but if you're sensitive to topics such as mental health, I would still recommend at least giving it a try since it doesn't just load it on you immediately. Is also a must buy for story game lovers.

Have you ever played a game? Crazy, right? Well let me be the first to inform you that your favorite game sucks unless it is this game.

Omori is unlike anything you have seen before, and I'm finding it very difficult to write this, not only because words cannot describe how absolutely immaculate it is, but also because going into any level of detail at all would put me at risk for spoiling it. Even talking about the first 2 hours of the game is somewhat a spoiler. The main thing with story games (and especially this one) is that playing blind is the penultimate act of good you can do for yourself. As a result, spoiler evasion was my number 1 priority in making this review. There are many aspects of the game that I was skeptical of initially that rebutted quickly and effectively; which I will go over now, followed by some base coverage to give you a better understanding of what we're working with. Afterward, I will discuss particular aspects of the game that I found relatable to myself in order to hopefully allow you to draw connections from your experiences.

First, I will go over the gameplay basics. By far my biggest concern was this: I hated RPG turn based combat, and I hated horror (games). Even in the first 20 minutes of the game I was pleasantly surprised at how well integrated they were with the overall flow, which prevented me from hating it. [spoiler] The combat, instead of using types like Pokemon to create interactions, instead uses emotions; which is not only a unique concept, but it also has major relevance to the story, such as heavy foreshadowing. [/spoiler]. Despite having practically zero RPG game experience, I found it incredibly easy to get into. As a whole, the game introduces itself exceptionally, and as a result, allows the story to show itself at a perfect pace while allowing people such as myself to get a hang of it.

The game primarily goes back and forth between two types of segments, which I will not go into detail of for the sake of spoilers. Throughout the experience, you meet many interesting characters, both main or otherwise, that really enhances the world and encourages you to explore and visit everything (which you should definitely do). The soundtrack introduces new motifs at every corner, and the incredibly diverse settings always pique your interest. Although it shares many basic aspects with other RPG maker games, it puts a subtle twist that makes it feel off.

Anyway, let's cover some spoiler-free story basics. You play as a 12 year old boy named Omori, and you traverse the game's world "headspace" alongside your group of close friends: Kel, Hero, Basil, Mari, and Aubrey. Kel and Hero are brothers, while Mari is your older sister. You're free to wander and explore the whimsical characters and settings to your heart's desire. Well, that about covers all of the bases, so let's move on.

Next, I will go over some parts of the game that I found generally relatable in such a way that made it hit different and stand out. I understand by this point it seems slightly redundant to say "I want to dodge spoilers" or whatever. To give you context of how impactful this game is when you go in blind, I'll tell you this so you understand why I'm treading carefully: Even after almost a year since I played this game for the first time, I still think about it everyday. There is zero hyperbolic intention or exaggeration in that statement. Let me compare it to another game I love to death, Red Dead Redemption 2. Don't get me wrong, it was also an absolute banger of a game, but when I played Omori I couldn't help but think RDR2 got put to shame. The story and setting was also beautiful in its own right, but I first played RDR2 three years ago and I don't really think about it often. Even during the first year after I played it, it was often a background thought. Not Omori though, not Omori. 

Oh yeah, I forgot to mention, my story summary from earlier didn't give close to the whole picture. "Oh but wait!" I hear you saying, "This is a psychological horror game! It is the main tag that people put on this game!", and you're right. I'm partially lying to you. There's much, much more to the story that you should find out yourself. Don't worry though, it does not matter what kind of person you are. Even if you take little interest in facets of mental health, or you're scared because mental health is a sensitive topic for you, it's not a big deal. The game eases you into it, so you're not bombarded immediately. In fact, it's quite the opposite. Story beats are incredibly vague and always leave you guessing. It sounds like horrible story design, but it all catches up to you in the end as one massive depressing, but gratifying, haymaker. Except, the game's metaphorical fist is covered in barbed wire, and you're standing on the cliff edge of a volcano.

Well, why do I care so much? Well I guess the first part is because it felt criminal letting it ferment in my mind for so long, but also because this game has changed me forever. They did their research. It is horrifyingly accurate to what PTSD and depression are like realistically. As somebody who is majoring in this field, with personal experience in some of the parts of the mental health topics explored (that I won't tell random people on Steam as some random bozo writing a review), I implore you to just buy it right now.

Despite all of this, I still feel like I have not done the game justice, and I don't think it is possible with a review, either. It's just one of those "you have to play/do it to understand" type of things. As disconcerting or unhelpful as that is, I promise you that this game fulfills that title more than any other game out there.

You know what, forget the rest of this review, just buy it already. Every second you spent sitting here not buying it has only made me more and more angry.

11/10. Cannot even properly describe how many emotions this journey of a game made me feel. Never before have i played something and felt like *I* was in trouble, like *I* was the one who was losing a close friend, like *I* was the one trying to face my fears and the truth. That whole heavy, emotional rollercoaster, and its STILL an exceptionally impressive RPG. Has a better story than any visual novel ive played, while still having some flawlessly executed gameplay, art, and ESPECIALLY music. This game very noticably pays homage to Earthbound with its visuals and gameplay, Yume Nikki with its darker, more mysterious area design, art, and existentialism, and even Undertale with its sense of humor and lovable characters.

Overall MASSIVELY recommend this game to anyone looking for a tearjerker to get invested in, and even moreso to someone who had enjoyment with Undertale, Earthbound, Deltarune, or Yume Nikki.

Big thank you to OMOCAT and the whole dev team for making this absolute timeless masterpiece.

134667641.review: Mannnnn, this game is very polarizing. It has some of the highest highs of a game ever, especially story wise. The way the story is told and the way that you are supposed to think about it is EXTREMELY tight, and comes close to feeling perfect. Just when you actually think about the story and rules of the world... it starts to fall a part a bit and has many underbaked aspects. NOT TO MENTION HEADSPACE. The game is incredibly bloated, full of very over ambitious, amateur-esque moments of writing that feel more like OMOCAT is hanging onto her past ideas to heavily instead of embracing what the story had truly become. It makes the replay value completely tank, and just throws off the pacing and game in general, it's filer in the worst way possible with very few moments that make you go 'wow I see how this is relevant'. The combat system is cool though, little bit similar to earthbound, sure, but overall that's fine. Found it overly easy however, which sounds dumb because I just complained about filler and adding actual grinding would be even more annoying but I kinda wish I actually feared the bosses, instead I just killed through filler and then waited for 2-3 straight bosses, not exactly the most fun. THE EMOTION SYSTEM IS SO GOOD BUT TOTALLY UNDERDEVELOPED WHY OMOCAT?? But like I said, ignoring some of the smaller things, and a large thing or two, it is an experince that totally rewards paying attention and will pull on all of your emotional heart strings. 8/10

134240753.review:
[b] Content warnings for this game: Flashing lights, suicide, depression, panic attacks, self-harm, phobias [/b]

This game exceeded every expectation I had for a story game I think I ever could have had.

When working in RPG Maker, you're always trying [i] really [/i] hard to make the game NOT look like it was made in RPG Maker. Some things are inevitable. Tile-based movement. Top-down view. Limited graphics. But even with those limitations, I was incredibly impressed with how far they managed to push the envelope on it. The combat is IMMENSELY charming. The cut-scenes feel incredibly well-made. The worlds are colorful and bright and incredibly polished. It feels immersive, well-executed, and incredibly novel in a space that doesn't have a whole lot of extra room for novelty anymore.

The main story line of this game is phenomenal. The characters are charming and incredibly lovable, each one incredibly well-crafted. The fact that after a month of no longer playing the game, I can still remember most, if not ALL the characters, is an incredible feat not many games can pull off. I really don't want to spoil any of the content in the game, but it definitely is a game that sends your emotions on a roller coaster through so many bizarre feelings I've never really seen a game explore. It explores some really REALLY dark places. I've already put content warnings for those places up at the top. It will contrast it with some of the most wholesome, light-hearted fluff. And then it will mix the two together into such a bizarre hodgepodge that'll have you wondering how on EARTH does someone come up with this stuff. Overall, it's a story that I think anyone and EVERYONE can find interesting, and at least get something out of it, even if some might get more out than others.

Now, let's talk about the soundtrack. I didn't expect to like 100% of the music inside this game but GOD. Every. Song. HITS. From the cozier vibes, to the tear-jerks, to extremely tense high-stakes badass boss fights, this game checks every single box so effortlessly you'd think that the creator had done it before (Spoilers, they really haven't). If you're someone who plays games for the soundtrack, you will NOT be disappointed. Then again, when you have the likes of Toby Fox and Bo En putting songs into the game, was there ever any doubt?

The art in this game is incredibly well made, and is probably the greatest reason why this is NOT like every other RPG Maker game out there. OMORI has this really cute sketchbook style that is really easy to fall in love with and just left me wanting to see it more. I was genuinely super excited for every moment the game would swap to have me watch an animated cutscene because they were just SO GOOD. The designs go from cutesy to incredibly strange, to downright scary in such a seamless way it's almost disturbing. It was also probably the reason me AND you clicked on the game in the first place, so there's points to be had there, too.

Cons. Obviously [b] if you are sensitive to content and have issues with the content above, I would avoid this game like the plague. [/b] This story will DUMP it on to you in such high proportions you might not be able to handle it. It's also an incredibly personal game. This is not the type of game I would be comfortable showing to a stream or any sort of audience. It gets extremely vulnerable in ways I'm not okay with showing to other people. Please enjoy it at your own pace, by yourself. Now onto more tangible things, actual gripes with the game. In typical RPG fashion, even the more creative uses with the combat wear thin after a while. Turn-based combat as always, will get repetitive. It will not reward you for trying new things, as the combos and synergies that work early will work throughout most of the games without too much issue. From a gameplay perspective, I REALLY wish they pushed the envelope more and tried implementing new and exciting mechanics as time passed. Another thing is the diverging paths on storylines. I love having more personalized storytelling that doesn't hold your hand and instead allows you to make mistakes, I really can't help but think it wasn't amazingly implemented. There's basically two main storylines that are almost entirely based off of ONE incredibly mild-sounding decision. And even then, one of the storylines clearly had a lot more love put into it than the other, and if you aren't playing that one first, you may not have the stamina through the incredibly slow progression of that storyline to see the game through. It happened to a friend of mine playing the game, and it broke my heart. And yeah, it's a slow-burn type of story. It will tease you with plot progression in the form of confusing the hell out of you only for you to sit back with the final picture revealed and go "ohhhhhhhhh, okay." Playing the game a second time, I was basically thinking in my head "okay, can we move on from this fluffy cutscene and get to the good part?"

Overall, this is still one of my favorite indie games ever made. It's such a full-package game between the visuals, story, and music, that you just don't get to see very often. I want to say so much more, but I really want everyone to experience it in their own way. Like I said, it's a very personal game. Pace yourself, try not to listen to how other people want you to play it, or the spoilers people give you, and enjoy the game for what you interpret it as.

10/10, am looking for additional therapy.

[b] Edit: Gonna add more into my review since I wrote the previous one at 4am and don't remember how to type. [/b]
I usually don't review games but when I do its usually silly but this I just had to express my emotions somewhere. To just tell you how I felt at the end its, "HOLY SHIT THAT WAS BEAUTIFUL" with some tears. The way how the game plays with your emotion is done brilliantly, some fucked up shit happens and the next thing you know something funny happens and you forgot what you just witnessed a few seconds ago and I have fallen for it everytime (so are others) I always forget that behind this happy, fun world hidden behind it are some traumatizing things, as if you were living in a "dream world." The characters, the instant I saw them I am in love with them, everyone has their own special thing which make them different from everyone else and its just so fun to watch them interact with each other. This game is not like every horror game where a jumpscare happen every 5 second, here its slow and then gone, its gives you this eerie feeling that Something is always watching you.

[b] Some spoilers after this [/b]

[spoiler] The amount of time I have gotten a few tears to full on crying was beautiful. Seeing Sunny coming out of his home and facing reality even if it hurts was somewhat relatable? I am not sure, what I am for sure is and I do remember is during this time when you returned back to white space after falling into the library and seeing everyone has just vanished and you are just alone. I was at the park and interacting with the mirror saying to play hide and seek and after that I found you just broke me. The reason is I remember when I was small I did not have any friends and seeing others playing and having fun small me was sad so I would play on my own and talk to my self and have fun alone, I still interacted with my classmates and such but having a small group to talk and have fun that I did not have and I was devastated, It went on for a while, while as in from PRESCHOOL UNTIL PRIMARY I did not have anyone who was a "real" friend but after that I met some good people and I forgot that this even happened. When I was playing at that stage in the game and seeing Omori playing himself, the memories just hit me like a truck and i just cried, cried that this was my childhood and its being played both here and in my head. After calming my self I continued on and beated Omori :D, got the good ending not the true :/
Also Watermelon. [/spoiler]

132395744.review:
Omori is a heartbreaking, disturbingly terrifying, physiological horror game. The game is around 20 hours long depending on your play style. and is worth every penny. As a person who typically like fast paced shooter games this was an odd nice change of pace. Every single character is a dynamic and loveable  character which I cant say the same for games like DOOM or Red Dead Redemption 2 (I mean characters like Kieran.) I can say 20 hours is the PERFECT amount of time to gather true connections with these characters. if one of them were to die you would feel very upset because every character has a understandable goal, personality, backstory, and loveable nature. But enough about the wonderful cast onto gameplay. Turn based combat is done with it own unique twists and turns that make it interesting. Omori, has very similar combat to that of Earthbound where every hit feels powerful and rewarding. Omori's combat can also be compared to that of Pokemon, but instead of types you have emotions, Happy beats Sad that sort of thing.  Hell OMOCAT even managed to make a turn bases combat sequence terrifying! On that note the main selling point the horror element... Perfection. The horror element takes advantage of the player being immersed in the atmosphere in some sections to scare them in a way I have never seen before. When I was playing through Omori I noticed Omori can make your heart beat faster and deeper, terrible gut feelings, the feeling of vulnerability, and being overwhelmed. When most people think of physiological horror they think thing like Doki Doki Literature Club this is the real deal, I personally believe OMOCAT had psychologist's on there team helping them with Omori.
Omori was a fantastic change of pace and was an tremendously enjoyable experience from start to finish I wish I could replay this for the first time again!



My favorite game of all time could not ask for a DLC or a sequel more! 10/10

131588754.review:
Omocat's long, hard work definitely paid off here in OMORI. I found the story to be extremely touching and interesting, although the pacing seemed to be a little off in the middle. My theory is that **SPOILERS AHEAD**




The headspace sections that were very long and drawn out were written that way purposefully, to "distract" the player from the main story at hand. While some of these areas did get a little annoying to get through (looking at you, Humphrey), the dialogue and battles were entertaining enough to have me keep playing. I didn't find I needed to use the emotion system much, other than spamming "happy" onto your entire party.
The stark contrast between the dream world and the real world is surprisingly well portrayed, and makes you forget at times that this was all made on RPGmaker. The retro style of art is charming, and fits well with the 90's timeframe the game occurs in. The hand drawn portions manage to get across Omocat's style very well. Loved all the Yume Nikki and Earthbound influences, and also noticed parts that reminded me of Undertale and EVA. 
9/10 only because I want the switch content to be available on PC too lol

131399964.review: This game is one of the best games ive played and will forever hold a place in my heart. The mixture of nostalgia, horror and general fun gradient so perfectly and works so well together. I would 100% recommend anyone curious about the game, thinking about getting it or those who have never heard of it TO GO PLAY IT RIGHT NOW and especially recommend to play blind (meaning without watching any content or spoilers about it). The gameplay is smooth and simple, although sometimes i did get a bit confused on what to do at times, ether way i managed to figure it out in the end. The characters are well fleshed out and developed, you can tell omocat put in a lot of work to make the characters fell as real as possible and create a connection with the player. I can admit, at parts i did get frustrated (mainly the bosses battles) but i still had fun jamming to the absolutely astonishing music that is composed for each area and each boss (special props to the final song, i cant say its name because i dont want to spoil anyone.) The story in the game itself is well thought out and executed perfectly, both the main route and the hikikomori route, which im doing currently (Routes are different pathways in a games story that are opened by a players decision, these often will have different endings)  This game has truly touched me and i can relate to every character in a personal level, i will go as far as to say that this game will forever be a special memory for me because of how much i can relate to it. Furthermore , the representation for mental health is impeccable and describes how it feels precisely and accurately. Once again i recommend anyone who hasnt to play omori right now. Thank you so much OMOCAT for creating this awesome game and i cant wait to see more content from you.

The most significant moments were all without text and most things were portrayed metaphorically (especially the dream world and white space), which makes them even heavier.

Although I liked the first half of the game, it might be boring to many people since it is a bit "softer". The main events of the game (which is also where the psychological horror aspect comes in) happen much later.

130731535.review:
I was given this game by my friend Super Spook and at first was hesitant. I’m not usually the kind of person who goes out of my way to play RPG’s. But I must say that Omori is one of the best experiences out there. The artstyle, beautiful. The soundtrack, amazing. The story, heartbreaking but powerful. 

Before I get too far, this game is best experienced completely blind with no spoilers. 

If you have not played the game please stop reading this review and take my word that this is one of the best games, no experience you will have from a game. Buy it, it’s well worth the money. 


----MILD SPOILERS:

Even just in the beginning of the game I was drawn in by the beautiful hand drawn art style and anime styled characters as well as the vibrant colours of the main characters in both Headspace and Faraway. As well as the eerily chipper and moody soundtrack of the game. Each area was incredibly well designed and each of the characters so interesting. I loved the beginning where everything seems so happy and safe until you get to Basil’s house and when Something finally appears. The daytime sections with Sunny are by far the most story heavy and interesting part of the game. To look at the locations, characters, and stuff in Faraway and finding the connections in Headspace is honestly a really fun game to play. 
It’s almost impossible to not compare Omori to Undertale. Both were made with RPG maker and share that distinct art-style, as well as some of the funny and creative ideas in the Underground and Headspace respectively. I loved Undertale’s combat because you were able to directly influence your character and in a sense how much damage you take. I was a little disappointed that Omori didn’t include any system like that, but the combat is by no means boring. The follow up, energy, and emotion systems make combat engaging and fun. The bosses are creative and fun to fight. I do think the emotion system should be a bit more important as I found myself most just not caring about emotions and just outlasting the fights with items, but maybe I’m playing the game wrong. 


=====MAJOR SPOILERS:

Omori primarily is a story game and you can feel that in the gameplay. I chose to play the Hikikomori route on my first play through which was a mistake. The game is best experienced going for the true ending. In the Hikikomori route you don’t learn about what happened to all the characters and it really neuters the story which sucks because the story really is beautiful. Finding out what happened to Mari was disturbing, and finding out what Omori and Basil did was horrifying. But also seeing how Sunny’s friends truly cared about him and also how Sunny fights Omori, a manifestation that was created to repress the truth, inspires hope that things will work out in the end. Truly a roller-coaster of a ride playing through the game.

I really want to compliment my favourite area in the game, Humphry. The whole idea that there is a laboratory inside a giant whale is insane enough. Not only that but, Humphry is able to fully control his entire body to the point of manifesting little Humphrys is just so creative. I did kinda see the twist coming where he eats you, if you can call it that, but even still it was amazing when it happened. The fleshy pink walls and bones protruding from the foreground and background really add to the environment. I’d also like to talk about Pluto. One of my favourite characters. Having the in universe explanation for why Pluto isn't a plant being that he escaped from the solar system and goes on to be a regular occurrence in the game is hilarious. He really is bursting with personality and I love it.

>>>>>>Spoiler's Over:

In all, this game is an amazing experience. Although, I do not recommend trying to complete all the achievements for this game. Some are really grindy and not the most fun to complete, requiring many playthroughs to get all the achievements. But nevertheless, I do recommend the game to anyone able to handle the disturbing content or really likes RPG’s. 11/10 would recommend. So I did.

129652181.review:
First and foremost: Play this on a different storefront (xbox app/gamepass or consoles), OMOCAT has implemented exclusive content that has yet to be brought to steam. I can't think of any fathomable reason as to why this has been done but it is. Most of it is on a particular route, but you'll want to go through this game multiple times.

That out of the way, OMORI is beyond a once in a lifetime game that I will never forget anytime soon. The combat is simplistic for an RPG with what is basically a rock paper scissors element, but I'll be honest it's not what you come to OMORI for. It's serviceable and perfectly fine to play with, but OMORI has far better things to offer you. The writing and characters made me deeply care for and sympathize with them unlike any other game has made me done before. It gripped me at times to the point where I couldn't put the game down because I just want to continue playing. I smiled, I frowned and I even ugly cried. Despite being fictional characters that I only knew for about 25-35 hours I felt like I was seeing the whole life of a friendship between a group of friends, making me long for something I never had in my life. There are very few things that can get me to feel this way anymore so kudos to OMORI for making me feel this way. Maybe it's just because I can sympathize with the main character in a huge amount of ways, I don't know. For sure though, don't look anything up for the game if you do play it. No wikis, nothing. Just play the game and let your decisions take you where they go. Only after beating it once should you do that, but you should still try to entirely avoid spoilers for the other route's ending.
Besides an incredibly well written story, the music is absolutely fantastic. From happy-go-lucky songs to ones that make me feel depressed, nervous or on edge it manages to do an excellent job of hitting all the right notes. The animation for the cutscenes is exquisite too, I'm a fan of 'unique' art styles that some artists can have for their work and OMORI is one of them, kind of a rough pencil/pen sketch style to it? Whatever you wanna call it I'm in love with it. OMORI blends cute, friendly "out of this world" themes that would fit right in alongside games such as MOTHER with paranoia-inducing creepiness. Don't go in expecting a horror game along the lines of other RPG Maker games like the Witch's House, Ao Oni or Mad Father, but instead a mash-up of MOTHER, heavy story/writing from To the Moon and notes taken out of psychological horror games such as Silent Hill.
On top of that there are multiple routes that you can take (mainly a 'good' path and a 'bad' path). One of them has more side content than the other, but the endings are vastly different so you'll want to do both of them regardless. There is also a few secret areas to find.

I'm not even usually the type of person to replay a game immediately after finishing it to pursue a different story route but I'll be doing exactly that. I'm kicking myself for not really noticing this game until 2 years after the fact when everybody else is done with it. I just really wish OMOCAT would bring the console/xbox app exclusive content over, it's the only thing keeping me from giving it a 10/10 score. Until then, it's a 9.8.

There may or may not be some heavy spoilers in this review.

Before I begin, I highly recommend you to go into this game with as little info about the lore as you can.

OMORI is a game about a boy (his name is your choice, but the default option is SUNNY, so let's go with that) and [strike]his dream alter ego[/strike] the manifestation of [spoiler]his guilt and regret[/spoiler] OMORI. The game starts out in your dreams where you meet some friends and enjoy your time together, but things go south really fast. The objective of the game (at least in the beginning) is to just fight your fears, but oh boy- that's really different from what you'll be doing about 15 hours later.

This game was an absolute emotional rollercoaster for me. I consider myself a pretty tough guy when it comes to this, but this game almost made me cry several times. The shock when you find out that [spoiler]Mari is dead[/spoiler] was, at least for me really big, [spoiler]This game leads you to think that she committed suicide only to reveal that you were the one who killed her when you least expect it.[/spoiler]

overall 11/10, I played this game for 20 hours straight, I need sleep, help

129272324.review:
[h1] Sixty-seven-and-a-half hours later... [/h1]
What a ride it has been.

I cannot remember the last time a game has resonated with me as much as OMORI has. Undertale, maybe?
What seems at the surface to be another indie RPG whose mother is the MOTHER series, OMORI has proven itself to rise far beyond anything that inspired it.

Without spoiling anything, the game's about overcoming escapism by confronting the harsh truth.
But there's more to it than this. So, so much more. (Spoilers, obviously.)

[spoiler] The game is utterly masterful in its plot with the accidental death of Mari, and what it chooses to reveal to you about its circumstances at what time. It's a slow boil, sure, but the game uses this to its advantage, slowly leading you along with a hint to the truth here, or a clue that shows something's not right over there, before overwhelming you by revealing everything within the last couple hours of gameplay. It's accurate, as if you were in Sunny's shoes, having repressed something for so long only for it to come flooding back within the span of three days. [/spoiler]

[spoiler] Don't even get me started on the duet. I'm not a very emotional person - I never have been and I never will be. That scene cut through my shell and pierced my heart like how a knife would go through butter. I cried profusely. No other game has come close to doing that to me before. [/spoiler]

I am fully confident in saying that this game will always hold a special place in my heart. It's [b] something [/b] that will stick with me forever.
I cannot recommend any other game more highly than this one. If you have only twenty dollars to spend, I beg you - spend it on this. (If it's on sale, that's even better.)

...oh, and happy second anniversary, OMORI! Here's to many more.

[hr][/hr]

TL;DR: I bought this game expecting psychological horror and got depression instead. 10/10 would let this game emotionally ruin me again.

9.5/10 Would recommend!

128021409.review:
[h1] Learn the Power of Love [/h1]
This is a powerful piece of narrative fiction that enables the player to connect to the experience of Sunny and his friends. JRPG combat is just a mechanism for the story, and doesn't present much difficulty, but there is still a lot of content to explore and enjoy! The game is beautifully crafted to simultaneously lure you to get lost in headspace while also yearning for the truth. 
Omori sets a wonderful precedent for games to not only teach empathy for trauma and mental illness, but also help people understand what it is like to struggle with [spoiler]  thoughts of self-termination [/spoiler] (and how it can seem like the only/preferable option). Ultimately, the power of the love we share is the what helps us persist and overcome.
Playing this game will probably help you grow as a person; You'll at least have quite a unique experience that masterfully presents the story of Omori!

127787794.review:
This is my favorite game of all time. 

Before I get into it, I should say that this game is best experienced blind, with the exceptions of the content warning and:
OPEN THE DOOR IN THE DAY. The game does not warn you at the time but it is a key moment that will completely change the game should you choose one or the other. The game is best experienced in a story aspect if you open the door. This is only one of the small gripes I have with this game. You will understand once you get to it. 

With that out of the way, I can say that the music, characters, and story are all top tier. I'll go through these without spoiling anything. The soundtrack to this game is amazing and constantly dishes out bangers. The characters are charming and the world building is phenomenal. It's quite easy to get soaked into the world if you care about the characters. As I don't want to spoil too much, all I can say about the story is that it's best experienced blind and that it's really amazing.

Now to address the minor complaints. Just because this game is my favorite and the best game I've ever played does not mean it is a *perfect* game. Besides the minor complaint mentioned earlier, another common complaint I see is the length of the game. Without spoiling too much, some feel that certain sections of the game could be shorter or not included at all. I will say that from a story perspective it makes sense why it is that way, but from a players perspective it might be seen as added fluff. However, if you play this game completely blind and just ride the wave, you could easily get immersed with the world and just learn to enjoy the moment.

Personally it took around 20+ hours to complete the game, but I am definitely planning on going back in to get close to 100% in this game. 

10/10 Game, go play it already.

125414126.review: I was blown away by this game that I found on Game Pass. At first, I thought it looked different from other games and decided to give it a try. However, the first jumpscare made me uninstall the game immediately. But, the game's storyline piqued my interest, so I searched for its lore on YouTube. After watching just one video, I reinstalled the game and invited my friends to play it with me. We almost finished one ending when the Game Pass ended. Even before it ended, I had already decided to purchase the game. It's a masterpiece in every aspect - the visuals, soundtrack, and story. Although I was disappointed that the Game Pass version was different from the Steam version, and I couldn't continue with my saves, it didn't diminish the gameplay and story's quality. In my opinion, this game is up there with Minecraft, Portal 2, and Half-Life; everyone should play it, even if they're not a fan of psychological horror games. It's unfortunate that the game isn't as popular as it should be, but I believe that one day, it will be recognized as one of the greatest games ever made. It's definitely worth the money, and I played most of it for free thanks to the Game Pass. I hope that Omocat will make the Steam version more like the console version, but that doesn't bother me too much. Thank you, Omocat, for creating one of the best games ever made. I'm certain that it will become more popular one day, and everything will be okay.

124699226.review:
I’ve played a lot of games, filled with good stories, imagery, and left me feeling satisfied. I’ve never had a game give me such a cathartic reaction before. Omori is more than a masterpiece, it’s a once in a lifetime experience.

Beyond the enjoyable gameplay and fun dialogue, jokes, and exploration; Omori does an incredible job delving into the topic of anxiety and depression. It’s not afraid to show the battle between one’s sanity and willingness to overcome their fear. I find myself relating to the characters and care deeply about what happens to them.

Yes, it’s a horror game, and typically these kind of games prevent me from experiencing great storytelling. Omori ironically helped me conquer my fear of  horror games and now I want to look more into the genre. I highly suggest those who are hesitant to trying Omori out to give it a shot. Yes, there are jumpscares, but they’re not cheap. They have meaning.

Omicat and the entire team made an amazing experience with this game. One thing I will say though is this:

I WILL NEVER LOOK AT TOAST THE SAME WAY AGAIN.

123658473.review:
Absolutely stunning. One of the few games that kept me thinking about it even after I finished it. While the gameplay isn't revolutionary, the story and mystery is what makes this game so special. Definitely worth getting if you enjoy a story that'll keep you engaged the whole way through.

The gameplay itself isn't anything special. Combat is simple turn based rpg maker combat, which isn't bad, but it's nothing new. Overall I'd say the gameplay is good.

Great soundtrack. Plenty of times where audio aids the atmosphere to amplify the experience.

You shouldn't have to worry about your pc specs for it.

The game itself isn't difficult. You wont be repeatedly dying to a boss and coming back annoyed. In my first playthrough I died less than 5 times. This doesn't mean the game doesn't have hard parts. I over prepared a lot which made some fights easier than they would have been. Overall, the difficulty is fairly simple, but can be challenging.

You don't need to grind at all to complete the game. It certainly can help to grind a bit but you don't have to if you don't want to. I myself grinded quite a bit early on which made fights easier.

The story is the main reason you play this game. Going into the game without knowing anything is recommended. The characters, environments, and interactions all fit together in a way that just makes the game charming. Not to mention how stunning the ending is.

It's a pretty long game, taking just over 35 hours to complete my first playthrough. Keep in mind I explored pretty much every nook and cranny I could, boosting my total hours. Without reading all the flavor text, I'd say the game is about 20-30 hours in length.

Absolutely worth the price for how much time the game takes. If it's on sale and you're debating getting the game, there's no reason not to get it.

I encountered no bugs in my time playing the game. You won't have to worry about bugs.

10/10

123595745.review:
Play OMORI without spoilers. That is to say, ASAP.
     What may seem like a standard cutesy RPG with a unique battle system hides so much depth. I don't mean like intricate stat systems, I mean story. It is true that the game does drag sometimes, especially in a certain section involving  a castle and a certain section involving a whale. That is, however, MORE than made up for in everything else. If you aren't an RPG person, I still recommend seeing a playthrough of it on Youtube. So, to the chase:
     OMORI is a game about OMORI, a boy who resides in WHITE SPACE, where he has been as long as he can remember. He leaves it daily to go and see his three other friends: KEL, HERO, and AUBREY. Alongside them is his best friend BASIL and his sister MARI. They have picnics, play games, take photos, and just have a great time. In the game, they even go around helping out the people of their happy world with problems and fighting monsters.
     Okay, you can see the trailers and images, what is all the black and white spooky stuff about? "Psychological Horror"? Yes, this is one of those games that hides a lot more than it lets on. DO NOT think this is another generic cutesy but actually evil game. There is story along with it, and it is amazing in my opinion. All the stuff you may have heard about this game making people cry, I can attest to. NEVER has any piece of media made me so much as tear up. No show, no movie, no book, no game, no music. That is, until this damn game. I streamed the whole game to someone on Discord, and the last hour or so of the game was in silence. After it ended, the dam broke. I just started crying. I won't talk about why exactly, if you finish the game or finish a video of it, you'll get it.
     Play this game as soon as you can, to avoid spoilers. It is absolutely as good as everyone has been saying. If it doesn't interest you or you don't enjoy it, that's okay too.
     This section will contain MAJOR spoilers. Read at your own risk.
     [spoiler] Ho-ly shit. The last hour of this game is worth some of the slower parts of HEADSPACE. BLACK SPACE, the Truth, the FINAL DUET. I still can't even think about the final duet without getting sad. Especially the part near the end where MARI saves SUNNY and it cuts to him alone, now in WHITE SPACE trying to block out the truth of her death. I also got the true good ending for watering BASIL's flowers each day. The final part where they smile to eachother was the straw the broke the camel's back for my tear ducts, more out of the rush of emotions. Sadness about the events, happiness about them being able to move on, anxiety about how the others would react. Luckily, the game keeps their reactions up to the imagination. I personally think Aubrey would need time to sort her emotions but would forgive them, Hero would need the longest time and may not even fully forgive them, and Kel would be the mediator trying to keep the group together. Hero did say they shouldn't leave eachother in a time of need like the last time. This game is an absolute masterpiece, and one of the best games I've ever played.  [/spoiler]

tl;dr: play it asap to avoid spoilers, watch/play it fresh, and be ready for emotion

147695888.review:
So, there's a lot... In every sense.

I mean, the game is quite long and it feels like it shouldn't be that way. And there's a lot to keep in mind, which is kinda hard since the game switches between two worlds, with every turn taking enough time to forget what you did before you switched. And also, there's a lot of emotions to deal with, a whole spectrum of them, starting with happy (also sad and angry if yk what I mean) moments, finishing with uncertainty and confusion about some of the characters' stories.

All these points are kinda controversial, I know, and I totally wouldn't recommend this game for everyone. The thing I liked the most was digging through the stories of characters, their motifs (are there any motifs for something you didn't mean to do?), feelings , thoughts and I could keep this list going. This game gave me space for thinking, which is why I liked it. It just feels good to do some thinking from time to time, you know. Like, would I act the same way? Would I feel the same? Why did it happen like that? What could it mean? Stuff like that. I also enjoyed finding little secrets (it implies backtracking, which I enjoyed too, it had its little details), thinking through battle tactics and hoarding. Plus, I don't mind some grind, so there's that.

Art and soundtrack are judged subjectively, but I liked those a lot, it's simple yet it fits so perfectly. I'm into this kind of aesthetic, so yeah, that counts too.

And I know the line of thought in my review is scattered all over the place, so as my thoughts about this game. I started playing it 3 times, 2 of them I quickly lost interest, the 3rd time I'm finally close to finishing it. At least I think so. Would've I lost a lot, if I hadn't played it? I don't think so. Would I recommend it? Yes, somewhat as a piece of culture, if I may say so. It's something that you should play and think through for yourself. The story was quite controversial for me, I don't agree on some things, I don't believe some things, but it made me think a lot. Give it a try, maybe you'll like it.

And here could be my staircase joke, but idk, just imagine there is one.
